post_text:
Would love to hear thoughts from anyone who has done programs instead of packages for their practice. 

I‚Äôve heard of this idea and played with in my head a bit and like the concept. I like the idea of committing to a program and outcome instead of set number of visits.

Am curious to hear from those who have done it how they have broken that down? And pros/cons or other things to consider from doing it?

comments.text:
I personally love the idea of programs as it makes your offer much more about what the patient actually cares about. I often compare it to someone remodeling my kitchen - I don't pay them to come to my house for 5 days, I pay for a remodeled kitchen! The challenge with PT obviously is that it isn't just reliant on the PT but also the patient doing what they're supposed to. 

That is where programs are very helpful -- you have a little more clarity on outcomes as your program is usually tied to a specific injury/diagnosis. I also love the idea of a "conditional guarantee" where if the patient meets certain requirements (does their HEP, etc) then you can offer some sort of guarantee on outcomes. Something that 95% of clinics aren't doing and helps you stand out from the pack. 

My wife's clinic implemented something like this and it has made a huge difference. She says it also makes selling much easier for her as she has a program for their specific injury and you're just selling that vs. trying to guess how many sessions someone will need. She priced it at what she thought the max amount of sessions would need to be for her program -- if the patient gets better sooner than that then they are happy as they reached their outcomes faster and she is happy as that boosts her profit.
Benji Toh I think it can work well for things like post op ACL, hamstring strains, plantar fasciitis to name a couple. I haven‚Äôt tried this but I think it could work.

post_text:
Has anyone done Fascial Distortion Model (FDM) or Fascial counterstrain course ?
Have you used these techniques? How effective these are and are they worth the training cost?

I am debating between the two. My goal is to add something effective for back pain patients. 

Any input is highly appreciated.

TIAüôè

comments.text: I second the FCS shoutout that David Harvitz gave. It‚Äôs literally 95% of the reason I decided to start my own practice. It‚Äôs the single most powerful technique I‚Äôve come across. When I first heard about it I thought it was too good to be true, but fortunately, I couldn‚Äôt have been more wrong. I‚Äôm not sure about FDM, but in FCS we‚Äôre addressing ALL fascia tissue throughout the body. Not only musculoskeletal tissue, but nerves, arteries, veins, etc. As a result, we can address more than musculoskeletal complaints. I have people come to me for IBS, fatigue/post COVID, anxiety, and a slew of other non musculoskeletal complaints. I probably sound crazy, but if I were you, I would take the first class and see if it piques your interest. Feel free to message me with any questions.
I've taken all the FCS courses. I help teach them and now host those classes. It is the most powerful set of techniques I've ever used in my 15 years as a PT. Worth every penny.

post_text: Do you girls have any suggestions for the courses I can do to deal more with clients having issues with intimacy targeting more on increasing pleasure? TIA

comments.text:
1) there is so much pelvic floor has to do with pleasure
2) there is so much mental/emotional stuff that goes into pleasure. P*rn and such can actually make it to where the brain struggles without this specific stimulation 
3) there is so much stress management that plays into the situation. 
4) your patient has to know what works for them and know what is actually normal vs what culture says is. 

There are cohorts for sexual counseling for PTs. Not sure if you already have this or not but you definitely need to be a pelvic floor PT to assess external, internal and pelvic fascia before/in conjunction with the other sides of this. 

Pleasure is a very layered topic and changes patient to patient, by region, by situation, etc

GPHAM sex counseling. Lots of recommended books there too. Books I refer to patients a lot are by Emily Nagaski: Come as you are and Come Together. It‚Äôs the science behind sex. Love these books especially since they are evidence based.

This is the same for working in acute care - if I patient had a BM on the floor or their chux were soiled with urine, it all just went in the trash. post_text:
Asking for a friend (that friend is me)- 

I bought my 17 year old volleyball playing son a massage gun for Christmas because "all the boys use them". He is interested in pursing a career in PT/athletic training/etc. I want him to use it correctly and show his teammates how to use the device correctly. I went down a YouTube rabbit hole looking for reputable videos on the science/physiology/technique but couldn't determine which videos were really legit/evidence based. Are the TheraBody videos any good? 

I thought this group would love able to help me out. Please post links of videos, articles, webinars, etc on massage guns that would be age/audience appropriate. Thanks in advance

comments.text: Personally I do a lot of hands on manual therapy and I hate the massage guns for rehab. I think they're not bad in muscle recovery after a workout, but find them to be of limited use in real rehab techniques. The oscillation is really only good when used directly on the muscle, but I find most problems in the tendons and bursae around the joint, kinda hard to get into those areas with a massage gun, the head attachments are usually too bulky, and you cant really "feel" the tissue for inflammation. I'd rather just use gua sha tools or my hands.

Honestly I don‚Äôt think there is really a ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù way. It‚Äôs great for recovery if you‚Äôre sore but otherwise it‚Äôs mostly just a feel good. I treat a ton of runners and triathletes and mostly tell them to just avoid overdoing it to the point of bruising themselves- something I have seen way too often!

post_text:
Any advice on starting a mobile, cash based dry-needling service? 
Thinking of primarily marketing to ENT and Dentist in small town for TMJ and Headache cases first and then branching out based off word-of-mouth.

Also wanting to avoid conflict of interest with my current employer.

comments.text: Whatever you do, please do not market it as a dry needling practice. You are either a PT, an OT, a chiropractor, etc. Dry needling is one tool in your overall toolbox and should only be used as part of a holistic plan of care, regardless of the diagnosis or patient in front of you. We are fighting for multiple professions to be able to dry needle in multiple states and using dry needling as a standalone intervention is putting many of us at risk for losing the privilege. Thanks in advance.
I would suggest you join the formal Uncaged Clinician coaching group. Not only would it give you the exact steps that you need, but also specific ongoing support. David Bayliff is incredible.

post_text:
Hey gang! So, long story short, I am emotionally compromised when it comes to a personal injury and I need your input. 

10 weeks/p AC sprain, likely type 5. Initial x-rays looked like it was a 2 but Ortho said 5 based on how prominent/mobile AC is (I agree). Full motion currently with minimal pain during ADLs. 

My only concern is the joint hyper mobility especially while sleeping causing some pain in the morning that is consistent. I also can press about 60 percent weight in the gym out front and overhead. External rotation in an outreached motion also hurts. I also feel some separation/pain during these movements. This has gotten a bit better the past week. 

My schedule really only allows surgery mid-December otherwise I round trip a potential surgery until next year. Doc thought the outcomes wouldn't change a whole lot waiting a year (if I did do it). I actually disagree here albeit not by a huge margin. 

Any thoughts? Advice? Do it? Don't do it? Type 5 isn't usually treated conservative and information on this is limited.

comments.text: Brace it and try to minimize irritation. Not worth it. Wait till surgery.

Thomas, I think your decision should be based on your long term goals.  if you‚Äôre going to wait on surgery, then you know that your rehab has to be top-notch. Not only stabilizing everything around the AC joint, but making sure that you have proper mobility through rib cage thoracic spine, scapula and GH joint so that AC joint is not further strained to accommodate the lack of motion at those areas.Ôøº

Not only stabilizing everything around the AC joint, but making sure that you have proper mobility through rib cage thoracic spine, scapula and GH joint so that AC joint is not further strained to accommodate the lack of motion at those areas.Ôøº

post_text:
Has anyone does back to back sessions with a patient before? For example: Monday and Tuesday.

This is a trend I am seeing near me from a local orthopedic group. I feel some can handle this but patients may be tired from back to back says. What are your thoughts? Any pros that I may be missing?

comments.text:
I always envision each session an extension of the last, you either diversify or you stack on what was already done. 

However,  if you're not making the POC for your patients and doing what you believe is right for their situation you're giving away your autonomy.

Depends on the diagnosis.

Total knee, and we're working on hard stuff that I KNOW requires recovery time? No. Not doing back to back. 

Balance stuff? Tons of room to mix things up. Can easily do back to back, even if the activities are moderate intensity for that individual.

full_thread_text:
POST: Has anyone does back to back sessions with a patient before? For example: Monday and Tuesday.

This is a trend I am seeing near me from a local orthopedic group. I feel some can handle this but patients may be tired from back to back says. What are your thoughts? Any pros that I may be missing?

COMMENT 1: I always envision each session an extension of the last, you either diversify or you stack on what was already done. 

However,  if you're not making the POC for your patients and doing what you believe is right for their situation you're giving away your autonomy.

COMMENT 2: Depends on the diagnosis.

Total knee, and we're working on hard stuff that I KNOW requires recovery time? No. Not doing back to back. 

Balance stuff? Tons of room to mix things up. Can easily do back to back, even if the activities are moderate intensity for that individual.

post_text: Does or has anyone seen a patient 2x a week for maintenance? Let‚Äôs say neuro conditions a like MS or Parkinson‚Äôs

comments.text: Yes but you need to have strong documentation for objective measures and impact on quality of life. You also need to vary your frequency to show the patient declines in quality of life and function with less therapy.

I have done this with 2 Medicare patients in the past. It took a lot of documentation and coordination with their provider to sign off on it when needed. The one was younger and was on disability his whole life due to a rare neuro disorder. We had years of history of him doing regular PT, discharging, declining and returning to PT. He did so well with the maintenance program! He was able to start working and eventually took a full time job that was flexible with him and he was able to get off Medicare disability! Last I heard he was still working and loving it. I was so proud of him.

full_thread_text:
POST: Does or has anyone seen a patient 2x a week for maintenance? Let‚Äôs say neuro conditions a like MS or Parkinson‚Äôs

COMMENT 1: Yes but you need to have strong documentation for objective measures and impact on quality of life. You also need to vary your frequency to show the patient declines in quality of life and function with less therapy.

COMMENT 2: I have done this with 2 Medicare patients in the past. It took a lot of documentation and coordination with their provider to sign off on it when needed. The one was younger and was on disability his whole life due to a rare neuro disorder. We had years of history of him doing regular PT, discharging, declining and returning to PT. He did so well with the maintenance program! He was able to start working and eventually took a full time job that was flexible with him and he was able to get off Medicare disability! Last I heard he was still working and loving it. I was so proud of him.

post_text:
For those that work with Parkinson‚Äôs patients- how soon after a DBS surgery do you see them?

I thought it was a while- till the settings were determined but I had a patient call me today. She was cleared by her surgeon about 2.5 weeks after the surgery to start light therapy. Are there specific protocols I should be aware of? Just wanted to inquire or see others thoughts as I thought this was kind of soon, especially after a big surgery like this.

comments.text: Worked acute care for a while. We saw DBS post op same as anyone else to make sure they could return home safely. Curious what others will say, but my thought is that even if the settings are still needing adjusted and they don‚Äôt have it completely figured out yet, they still have to function at home and a fall would only impair their healing, so seeing them and helping them be safe and learn makes sense to me.
In outpatient we saw them pretty early on. Usually 1-2 weeks post. Surgeon obviously takes the lead but many of times they were very receptive to our opinion.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those that work with Parkinson‚Äôs patients- how soon after a DBS surgery do you see them?

I thought it was a while- till the settings were determined but I had a patient call me today. She was cleared by her surgeon about 2.5 weeks after the surgery to start light therapy. Are there specific protocols I should be aware of? Just wanted to inquire or see others thoughts as I thought this was kind of soon, especially after a big surgery like this.

COMMENT 1: Worked acute care for a while. We saw DBS post op same as anyone else to make sure they could return home safely. Curious what others will say, but my thought is that even if the settings are still needing adjusted and they don‚Äôt have it completely figured out yet, they still have to function at home and a fall would only impair their healing, so seeing them and helping them be safe and learn makes sense to me.

COMMENT 2: In outpatient we saw them pretty early on. Usually 1-2 weeks post. Surgeon obviously takes the lead but many of times they were very receptive to our opinion.

post_text: Hi,I am a newbie, recently started my practice as pelvic PT and I have subleased a treatment room. I don't have hydrocollator yet but want to explore options what I can use. It's a little out of budget right now to buy one. Thank you

comments.text: Pelvic pt here.. a question for thought.. Why do you think you need a hydrocollator?

Totally can wait. Not worth the expense, space or upkeep in my opinion -especially if just starting out. 

Can you do the Medibeads that can be heated in a microwave or an electric hot pack like the one posted? 

We use hot packs very infrequently but patients do like the slight weight of the medibeads on their abdomen when we have used them and many times we just encourage them to buy one for home use so we can prioritize our in clinic time for other things they can‚Äôt do on their own. 

My approach might be slightly different though because I‚Äôm in insurance based clinic so we are limited to 45 to 60 minutes for appointments so I usually defer heat or ice so I can do more hands-on techniques or supervised exercises. Ôøº

post_text: Question: How would you start pre gait training on a 55 y/o male TBI patient with s/p pelvic fx and TTWB on R and only spontaneous movement on L LE? B radial fx with ability to use platform walker and WB through forearms.  Intermittently follows commands only.

comments.text: TTWB isn‚Äôt realistic in a patient unable to consistently folllow commands. Wait until he is cleared for WBAT or cognitive level improves enough for him to adhere to wt bearing status. Focus more on transfers, balance, strength etc‚Ä¶

In this situation I think pre gait activities for me would be to work on PNF patterns on the L LE to try and improve the muscle control, seated and supine exercises to strengthen the  R LE for when approved to WB fully. Balance in sitting, bed mobility, wheelchair mobility, participation in slide board transfer

full_thread_text:
POST: Question: How would you start pre gait training on a 55 y/o male TBI patient with s/p pelvic fx and TTWB on R and only spontaneous movement on L LE? B radial fx with ability to use platform walker and WB through forearms.  Intermittently follows commands only.

COMMENT 1: TTWB isn‚Äôt realistic in a patient unable to consistently folllow commands. Wait until he is cleared for WBAT or cognitive level improves enough for him to adhere to wt bearing status. Focus more on transfers, balance, strength etc‚Ä¶

COMMENT 2: In this situation I think pre gait activities for me would be to work on PNF patterns on the L LE to try and improve the muscle control, seated and supine exercises to strengthen the  R LE for when approved to WB fully. Balance in sitting, bed mobility, wheelchair mobility, participation in slide board transfer

post_text: I saw the recent post about a CEU course for ANF therapy, and after looking into it I have to be üíØhonest in that my BS meter went off the hook, and I consider myself pretty open to some of the more nebulous treatment ideas and approaches. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è  My question to the group is what all has been your experience with it? Is it worth it? Are there other companies beside the one mentioned that offer products where you don‚Äôt need to do thousands of $ in trainings to become licensed? I‚Äôm genuinely curious, and feel free to message me directly if you don‚Äôt want to offend anyone!üòÇ Link to the company referenced is below.

comments.text:
I practice it with every single private client and I‚Äôve consistently gotten better outcomes 2-3 times faster compared to without it (I also work insurance based part time and I‚Äôve tracked similar cases). There are results that still shock me to this day after using it for 3 years in ways that I can‚Äôt explain as just placebo‚Äîlike Kevin DeGroot mentioned too. 

Pain relief, restored motion and function in the first session, far quicker recovery time than with my manual therapy skill set + standard PT (and I also get good results already with manual techniques and pain neuroscience education, etc). 

I‚Äôve used it on my competitive athletes and those with chronic pain and comorbidities when ‚Äúnothing else is working‚Äù and both groups and those in between have been blown away by how fast and lasting this stuff is. 

It‚Äôs great because even on that initial treatment, my clients walk out the door with an average of 40-50% improvement on symptoms and restoration of activity progresses more consistently. 

I had a rancher with a ruptured biceps who couldn‚Äôt even put on his shirt or flex his arm above 60 degrees with chronic shoulder pain and within the same visit we got him to 160 flexion and putting his jacket back on pain free and then four weeks later he was roping cattle again. 

I‚Äôve also had a lymphedema protocol on a swollen leg experience like Kevin mentioned and watching it ‚Äúdeflate‚Äù as the swelling left in real time‚Ä¶both the client and my faces were üòÆüòÆ

Had a lady with sciatica and none of the traditional PT strengthening, stretching, or manual was helping her, but when I treated with her a gut protocol, and nothing on her sciatic nerve or associated hip muscles, her pain halved just as is. 

If you‚Äôre into whole-organism treatment, once you start learning and practicing with ANF, you see how everyone‚Äôs nervous system needs to be treated‚Äîmuch like how we can‚Äôt turn off our gait analysis eyes. üòÜ

post_text:
The VA covered dry needling but they barely paid anything. Enough to barely cover the needles we used.

We are in network with the VA so do we have to bill them the dry needling? Or can we just tell the patient we will not submit that and it will be self pay for the dry needling?

comments.text: You have to check your contract. I‚Äôve read in the past that if you are contracted with an insurance it is against the contract to make someone pay cash for covered services
Yes, you have to bill the VA. You cannot charge them cash for covered services if you are in network with the VA.

full_thread_text:
POST: The VA covered dry needling but they barely paid anything. Enough to barely cover the needles we used.

We are in network with the VA so do we have to bill them the dry needling? Or can we just tell the patient we will not submit that and it will be self pay for the dry needling?

COMMENT 1: You have to check your contract. I‚Äôve read in the past that if you are contracted with an insurance it is against the contract to make someone pay cash for covered services

COMMENT 2: Yes, you have to bill the VA. You cannot charge them cash for covered services if you are in network with the VA.

post_text:
Hi my fellow clinicians,

I was contacted to give a presentation at 55+ community clubhouse especially for tennis ball/pickle ball/golf players ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

I have definitely worked with patients playing these sports and guided them well but I have never done a presentation for general info  and to educate them on ways I could help them. 

I would love to hear some ideas from people who have done it.

So far I am thinking :
-Flyer with basic education 
-Talk about muscle imbalance , posture, tennis elbow, prevention techniques, KT taping techniques etc.

Any further guidance on this is highly appreciated.üôèüôè

comments.text: I would provide a hand out on favorite post match exercises that focuses on decreasing those muscle imbalances. I think on mine I put child pose, upper trunk rotations, piriformis stretches, sleeper stretch. I agree on education focusing on hip, shoulder and thoracic mobility to help improve their games.

For geriatric golfers specifically I would work on hip and shoulder/thoracic mobility and strength. For a short part of a presentation I‚Äôd just say ‚Äúlow back pain in golf can be helped by getting a little more strength and flexibility in your hips > (insert how you would do it) > caution that it‚Äôs not the only thing that could contribute to low back pain and if they want a more thorough assessment you are happy to see them. Short and sweet, but as a golf focused PT I work on the hips for almost every patient

post_text: Any of my mobile PTs have neck pain from looking down at patients feet all day long? Constantly looking down while patients walk, do step ups, balance, etc. Am I the only one?

comments.text: Had severe neck pain in my 20‚Äôs/30‚Äô while working all day in clinic and doing paperwork at counters‚Ä¶no more issues at 47 since  beginning McKenzie exercises (progress to chin tuck with ext),  daily foam roll routine for thoracic mobility, and pec MINOR stretching.  Must gain extension and mobility at CT junction, and start out working on this every 2 hours (don‚Äôt just wait til you get home at the end of the day).  Hope you feel better!

When I was first in Pilates training (before PT school), the teacher trainer encouraged us to ‚Äúlook with your eyes, not your head‚Äù because we could develop neck pain fully looking down on mats and reformers all day long. That stuck with me, along with the expectation that I should have proper posture if I was to preach it all day. Lying on a foam roller before bed also does wonders.

full_thread_text:

Must gain extension and mobility at CT junction, and start out working on this every 2 hours (don‚Äôt just wait til you get home at the end of the day).  Hope you feel better!

post_text:
Question for fellow PTs:
I‚Äôve been seeing a dialysis patient on and off for ~2 months with a history of severe cervical and lumbar stenosis, chronic pain, balance deficits, and frequent falls (2‚Äì3/week). Initially, therapy focused on gait, balance, stair training, and functional strengthening. He could tolerate 1-hour sessions (likely his most active time of day), and he made good progress.

About a month ago, we paused PT to let the family consult doctors for pain management, BP, and blood sugar issues. During that time, his nephrologist adjusted his dialysis fluid removal to help with BP. Since then, the daughter reports he has had increased weakness, shakiness, and difficulty walking, requiring more caregiver assistance.

On follow-up, he tolerated the session well and felt good afterward, but I see a lack of structure and consistency with his home exercise program, which I think is contributing to ongoing decline.

My question: How do you typically approach prognosis conversations with families in complex cases like this where the patient has medical instability, frequent falls, and fluctuating function? Would you recommend a different approach? If so what kind of approach and how do you community this to the family. The family is really worried about the patient and because of a lack of ‚Äúgoods insurance‚Äù the patient is not getting the proper care from his medical team. I‚Äôve communicated my thoughts to the family but wondering how else everyone may approach it!

Thanks and anymoyous because some people will know who the patient is if I post as myself.

comments.text: This sounds tough. I would probably approach as safety training and how to use the proper equipment to prevent falls. Once CGs and pt does that with less falls, I would potentially even DC if medical situation fluctuates too much. Sometimes I frame it as saving their PT visits for when we can make more progress and for when they‚Äôll really benefit it. If their medical condition prevents progress, it‚Äôs also really hard to justify on  a note and can risk insurance denial. I straight up tell the family how insurance works and that we need to show progress and medically necessary treatment and respond to continue. I‚Äôll be firm but kind is saying more than 1x/ week or every other week will not be justifiable with current condition but when their condition improves, we can try increased frequency again..

full_thread_text:
POST: Question for fellow PTs:
I‚Äôve been seeing a dialysis patient on and off for ~2 months with a history of severe cervical and lumbar stenosis, chronic pain, balance deficits, and frequent falls (2‚Äì3/week). Initially, therapy focused on gait, balance, stair training, and functional strengthening. He could tolerate 1-hour sessions (likely his most active time of day), and he made good progress.

About a month ago, we paused PT to let the family consult doctors for pain management, BP, and blood sugar issues. During that time, his nephrologist adjusted his dialysis fluid removal to help with BP. Since then, the daughter reports he has had increased weakness, shakiness, and difficulty walking, requiring more caregiver assistance.

On follow-up, he tolerated the session well and felt good afterward, but I see a lack of structure and consistency with his home exercise program, which I think is contributing to ongoing decline.

My question: How do you typically approach prognosis conversations with families in complex cases like this where the patient has medical instability, frequent falls, and fluctuating function? Would you recommend a different approach? If so what kind of approach and how do you community this to the family. The family is really worried about the patient and because of a lack of ‚Äúgoods insurance‚Äù the patient is not getting the proper care from his medical team. I‚Äôve communicated my thoughts to the family but wondering how else everyone may approach it!

Thanks and anymoyous because some people will know who the patient is if I post as myself.

COMMENT 1: This sounds tough. I would probably approach as safety training and how to use the proper equipment to prevent falls. Once CGs and pt does that with less falls, I would potentially even DC if medical situation fluctuates too much. Sometimes I frame it as saving their PT visits for when we can make more progress and for when they‚Äôll really benefit it. If their medical condition prevents progress, it‚Äôs also really hard to justify on  a note and can risk insurance denial. I straight up tell the family how insurance works and that we need to show progress and medically necessary treatment and respond to continue. I‚Äôll be firm but kind is saying more than 1x/ week or every other week will not be justifiable with current condition but when their condition improves, we can try increased frequency again..

post_text:
I was asked to be on the sideline for a local football team, during their games. I haven't the faintest Idea on what all I need to know or be able to do? Alongside would be an ortho surgeon who is the official "Team Doc" but he apparently sucks and isn't that great to work with. I know the head coach very well and he has been an old patient of mine who I helped avoid a surgery. He sends me a lot of his football guys. But I just want to know what all I need to know or be able to do?

I just rcently started doing a lot of ultrasound and I'm in the process of getting my RMSK. So I showed him a lot of the ultrasound that we do and also a lot of the manual muscle testing/force plate eval's we can do and of course dry needling.

My main goal was to establish communication with the athletic trainer and directly with the coaches as well in case they ever need to send me someone urgently, etc etc

comments.text: I see this topic brought up a lot. In short - don't do it. I'm a DPT, OCS, SCS, and a host of other certs. Part of getting and maintaining the SCS involves venue coverage and an Emergency Response for Athletes cert. It takes training and preparation to be ready and qualified for venue coverage. If you haven't done the prep work, dont try to provide the venue coverage.

Even if you have an idea of what to do, if you don't have the appropriate training, do not do it. You can be held liable in the event of an unfortunate incident. Message this fact to the coach and offer your urgent orthopedic care only and not on the sideline.

An old patient of mine. He‚Äôs the head coach at a big school near me. We have a good relationship.

He is coming to my clinic this weekend and I‚Äôm going to show him some new stuff we have now. Like balance testing. Manual muscle testing. Ultrasound imaging. And my goal is to test all of his athletes. I‚Äôd love ti di like a weekend workshop and go setup at their school and pick a few kids to test  

My question is: should I charge anything? Like $40/kid? I could create a flyer and the coach can send it out to the parents explaining what all we will be doing and how beneficial it can be.

Or should I do this for free?

comments.text:
A few kids,  offer free.  A whole team, your choice.  We had an ortho physician offer free sports physicals one night to our high school team. Who do you think they'll go to when they are injured? He also is very busy and doesn't need  a much bigger load,  so just genuinely nice as well. 
I've also seen discounted exams/screens etc. 
I'd say,  what's your goal? Get in with the team? Make money off this particular offering? A favor for an old client? Go from there.

I‚Äôm a high school coach and PTs offer to come in and do functional strength testing for my team for free all the time.   As a PT myself I have never needed this, but other coaches I know have done it and it‚Äôs a great way to get in front of athletes and tell them what you can do to help them.

post_text:
Not sure if I can post this here - lmk where I can post if not allowed:
Update: 10/7/25 @6mos post-op (4/11/25 Surgery)
For those who commented on recs and knowledge, thank you! Here is the status of her shoulder. We‚Äôve gotten 3 other opinions from ortho docs and they all agree it looks like it‚Äôs buldging out. One doc is calling the rep of the hardware company and asking what size was put in. Another Doc said it looks like it was placed at an angle and more lateral or anterior than he would‚Äôve placed it. But that doesn‚Äôt mean that it warrants a revision. The deltoid appears to be missing anteriorly ??? but she‚Äôs able to flex at shoulder to 90*, 2/5 MMT w/ pain/wincing. The sunken look is progressively getting worse.  

We are hoping the rep says that a partial revision can be done to replace with a smaller disc between the neck of the hardware and the ball without replacing the entire set. Anyone have insight to this situation?!

Updated info: I need advice from ortho PTs.
My (medicare/75yo) mom‚Äôs reverse total shoulder 3.5 mos post-op prosthetic looks odd. 
It keeps catching w/ pain 10/10. Doc says it‚Äôll take time and patience. He used an off-the-shelf prosthetic and says he rarely orders custom. Are off-the-shelf cheaper??? How can I be reassured it‚Äôs the correct size since he‚Äôs sure it‚Äôs the correct size? She was 120* should flexion and now 85* with bruising post 4 days ago, she reached up behind her head to put her sling on to just rest it and she got stuck 10/10 worst pain shes ever been in‚Ä¶she didnt hear a pop, but could it have dislocated? Doc says maybe so but didn‚Äôt give us a plan post subluxation. He said to rest it, dont do IR for awhile, and itll ‚Äúheal‚Äù. üò≥

So many red flags during our visit today showing no compassion and strong resistance to admitting anything other than she needs to be patient. He actually called to apoligized but it was a,‚ÄùIm sorry, but‚Ä¶‚Äù apology.  Rated TOP REVERSE shoulder doc in Austin, TX and he said he is 1 of 6 who created this prosthetic!? What do we do? We have a 2nd opinion in a week. I‚Äôm in shock for my mom. üôè feri e t

comments.text: I‚Äôve treated many rTSA‚Äôs and just based on the images that DOES NOT LOOK NORMAL. Clearly she has significant atrophy so I‚Äôm concerned about nerve damage, but also the component doesn‚Äôt even look like it‚Äôs fitting properly. Yes reverse shoulder replacements can take six months up to a year to feel somewhat normal but if she is still struggling even with just functional movements, then a second opinion is absolutely needed. Hope that helps üôèÔøº

Sulcus like that can be prothesis but more commonly the deltoid weakness and scapular mm weakness is not assisting stabilizing inferior component. The deltoid is essentially the new prime mover for elevation so rtc atrophy like that happens. She will never have normal g/h pattern thats just reality of the surgery. I have seen large sulcus‚Äô like this- hardware was intact- there was just such long standing weakness . Rehab takes really long- lots of deltoid isometrics- I would make sure her PT is experienced in treating this.She could also have some adhesions forming limiting the rom and that is super painful too‚Ä¶ (think freezing phase of frozen shoulder). I would also use kinesiotape if safe on her skin to stabilize

post_text:
Hi everyone, I could really use some advice and perspective from this amazing group.

I‚Äôve been feeling a bit stuck lately‚Äîmy schedule recently went from fully booked to a little quiet, and it‚Äôs starting to impact my mindset. Some of the change is positive‚Äîseveral patients progressed faster than expected and were discharged early (which is great!), but I also think summer schedules and vacations are playing a role.

New patients are trickling in, but many are opting for visits spaced a week or more apart due to financial reasons. While I completely understand and respect that, it‚Äôs been tough from a business standpoint. I find myself spending even more time outside of sessions‚Äîchecking in, following up, and prepping between visits‚Äîand it‚Äôs starting to feel draining (not burnout, but close).

I‚Äôm slowly getting into social media, but it‚Äôs very time-consuming and I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve found my rhythm yet. My niche is pelvic health and chronic pain across the lifespan, mostly serving women, and while my patients are committed, their own full plates with work, family, and other medical appointments make scheduling consistent care tricky. We‚Äôve started offering some telehealth sessions, which helps, but overall, the dip is weighing on me.

This is the first real slump I‚Äôve experienced since opening. Friends and colleagues keep suggesting I contract with insurance for the short-term, then phase it out after growing my client base‚Äîbut that route feels overwhelming and not aligned with how I want to work.

Has anyone else navigated a slow season like this in a cash-based or hybrid pelvic health practice? What helped you stay afloat and continue growing while staying true to your values and energy? I truly love the work I do, and my patients are getting great results‚Äîit‚Äôs just the business side that feels heavy right now.

Appreciate any ideas, support, or even just solidarity üíõ

comments.text: Been uncaged 20 years.  Spring of 24' my scheduled dried up for a month or so.  Ebbs and flows of a new post covid environment.  Since u r uncaged, taking insurance will not change how u practice, but will change your reimbursement rate.  We took most when we opened, only take 2 now.

I have a similar practice. I‚Äôm a pelvic therapist and I do Dry Needling. I don‚Äôt take any insurance except for Medicare. I‚Äôm in Florida so summer definitely slows down seasonally. But I take advantage of it and take Fridays off in the summer. But if you have a cash based element to practice, you definitely have got to be engaged in social media on the regular. You have to have a foundation set up and then get yourself established in organic conversations through different Facebook groups that focus on your population. I have found this to be Very very helpful. I would strongly suggest against going with insurance. If you really feel like you need something temporary contract with a home health agency and do a little home health on the side. Also consider connecting with a home health agency and offering to do a Pelvic Floor program for them. Just a basic bladder training program nothing crazy because I don‚Äôt do internals in the home with the elderly. But teaching basic bladder health and having a program focused on incontinence in the elderly is fairly simple and straightforward, and it can be a good way to diverse by your practice and show up your schedule in times like this.   Ôøº also also connect with local outpatient physical therapist helped them identify your patient population to refer to you. I get a lot of referrals from massage therapist Chiropracter‚Äòs other physical therapist. They‚Äôre a great source of referrals. Also look for a business women‚Äôs networking group local. The one I belong to is very supportive about referring patients and it‚Äôs also been a great resource of patience ÔøºÔøº

While I completely understand and respect that, it‚Äôs been tough from a business standpoint. I find myself spending even more time outside of sessions‚Äîchecking in, following up, and prepping between visits‚Äîand it‚Äôs starting to feel draining (not burnout, but close).

I‚Äôm slowly getting into social media, but it‚Äôs very time-consuming and I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve found my rhythm yet. My niche is pelvic health and chronic pain across the lifespan, mostly serving women, and while my patients are committed, their own full plates with work, family, and other medical appointments make scheduling consistent care tricky. We‚Äôve started offering some telehealth sessions, which helps, but overall, the dip is weighing on me.

This is the first real slump I‚Äôve experienced since opening. Friends and colleagues keep suggesting I contract with insurance for the short-term, then phase it out after growing my client base‚Äîbut that route feels overwhelming and not aligned with how I want to work.

Has anyone else navigated a slow season like this in a cash-based or hybrid pelvic health practice? What helped you stay afloat and continue growing while staying true to your values and energy? I truly love the work I do, and my patients are getting great results‚Äîit‚Äôs just the business side that feels heavy right now.

Appreciate any ideas, support, or even just solidarity üíõ

COMMENT 1: Been uncaged 20 years.  Spring of 24' my scheduled dried up for a month or so.  Ebbs and flows of a new post covid environment.  Since u r uncaged, taking insurance will not change how u practice, but will change your reimbursement rate.  We took most when we opened, only take 2 now.

COMMENT 2: I have a similar practice. I‚Äôm a pelvic therapist and I do Dry Needling. I don‚Äôt take any insurance except for Medicare. I‚Äôm in Florida so summer definitely slows down seasonally. But I take advantage of it and take Fridays off in the summer. But if you have a cash based element to practice, you definitely have got to be engaged in social media on the regular. You have to have a foundation set up and then get yourself established in organic conversations through different Facebook groups that focus on your population. I have found this to be Very very helpful. I would strongly suggest against going with insurance. If you really feel like you need something temporary contract with a home health agency and do a little home health on the side. Also consider connecting with a home health agency and offering to do a Pelvic Floor program for them. Just a basic bladder training program nothing crazy because I don‚Äôt do internals in the home with the elderly. But teaching basic bladder health and having a program focused on incontinence in the elderly is fairly simple and straightforward, and it can be a good way to diverse by your practice and show up your schedule in times like this.   Ôøº also also connect with local outpatient physical therapist helped them identify your patient population to refer to you. I get a lot of referrals from massage therapist Chiropracter‚Äòs other physical therapist. They‚Äôre a great source of referrals. Also look for a business women‚Äôs networking group local. The one I belong to is very supportive about referring patients and it‚Äôs also been a great resource of patience ÔøºÔøº

post_text: How often are your patients having adverse reactions to dry needling?  I try to warn them that they may be sore for 1-2 days following our session but I feel like with upper traps specifically, my patients often have an increase in their pain for a few days.  Is there something I‚Äôm missing with upper trap techniques for dry needling specifically?

comments.text:
Describe your treatment approach - not enough information for anyone to accurately answer. 

I first learned dry needling from a more aggressive, piston-until-it-stops-twitching, treatment philosophy. I was so excited to use it in clinic the following Monday, and on the first patient I could - a pretty irritable glute tendinopathy. They did come back for a second session, thankfully, but asked that I never dry needle them again!

What I‚Äôve found over the years is that certain body parts are more sensitive to it, that certain people are more sensitive to it, that I had eventually gravitated to ‚Äúpiston less, stim more‚Äù before Paul Killoren coined it as a phrase, and that we always need to appreciate the symptom irritability of the patient before us.

I would treat that ‚Äúfirst patient‚Äù so much differently now than I had that day.

Soreness after needling for 24-48 hours isn‚Äôt uncommon but it shouldn‚Äôt be excessive, otherwise it‚Äôs an indicator that your techniques were likely too aggressive. 

The upper traps have an emergent point and motor point in the same ballpark so they tend to get extra ‚Äòtwitchy‚Äô - those local twitch responses from pistoning can definitely make someone pretty sore and achey, so have to feel out your clientele to judge whether or not you think they can handle it (and if it‚Äôs even appropriate)

full_thread_text:

I try to warn them that they may be sore for 1-2 days following our session but I feel like with upper traps specifically, my patients often have an increase in their pain for a few days.  Is there something I‚Äôm missing with upper trap techniques for dry needling specifically?

COMMENT 1: Describe your treatment approach - not enough information for anyone to accurately answer. 

I first learned dry needling from a more aggressive, piston-until-it-stops-twitching, treatment philosophy. I was so excited to use it in clinic the following Monday, and on the first patient I could - a pretty irritable glute tendinopathy. They did come back for a second session, thankfully, but asked that I never dry needle them again!

What I‚Äôve found over the years is that certain body parts are more sensitive to it, that certain people are more sensitive to it, that I had eventually gravitated to ‚Äúpiston less, stim more‚Äù before Paul Killoren coined it as a phrase, and that we always need to appreciate the symptom irritability of the patient before us.

I would treat that ‚Äúfirst patient‚Äù so much differently now than I had that day.

COMMENT 2: Soreness after needling for 24-48 hours isn‚Äôt uncommon but it shouldn‚Äôt be excessive, otherwise it‚Äôs an indicator that your techniques were likely too aggressive. 

The upper traps have an emergent point and motor point in the same ballpark so they tend to get extra ‚Äòtwitchy‚Äô - those local twitch responses from pistoning can definitely make someone pretty sore and achey, so have to feel out your clientele to judge whether or not you think they can handle it (and if it‚Äôs even appropriate)

post_text: How do you all figure out times per exercise ? If I have 60 minutes with a patient and 3 -5 minutes goes towards getting subjective and objective info that leaves 55 minutes. Rest/ transition time not billable. How do you document and justify your units. Does anyone have a system they use to meet these time requirements.  Guessing how long it takes and actually timing give different results depending on the pace of the patient and I find this time consuming to get accurate. Would love to hear how others do this quickly and accurately, justified documentation.  Thanks. I‚Äôm really on top of myself for this and wonder if most therapists are ethical about this requirement and how I can learn to be quicker.  I find myself adding lots of justification to my documentation to cya and I‚Äôm a seasoned therapist.  I find this requirement very challenging. But I do it for every patient.  Even cash patients that won‚Äôt be audited because I care about being consistent.  There has to be a better way than I am using.  One patient might take 3 minutes to do 3 sets of 10 each leg and another might take 6-7 minutes. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Would love to hear from you

comments.text:
For the record, I 100% think you are overdoing this.  I have never documented time per exercise.  I do document time per cpt code but never per exercise or rest break or any of that.  If you are spending one on one time with your client for an hour, all of that time is billable.  My note would look something like this:

97110 Therapeutic exercise (25 minutes) - strength and flexibility training to address deficits in XYZ strength and XYZ ROM

97530 Therapeutic Activity (20 minutes) - whole body activities to retrain balance, body mechanics, posture, and movement patterns during functional activities

97140 manual therapy (15 minutes) - MFR to XYZ and MET to XYZ to address pain and dysfunction 

And then below this description of my CPT codes I would list each exercise and/or activity performed. 

Therapeutic exercises and activities performed during this session: 

1.
2.
3.
Etc

This list would be thorough with reps etc but I would not list time per. 

Then in my assessment section I will document what cues were needed and response to exercise or improvements noted and challenges still present etc. 

I think documentation is already the worst part of the job and it sounds like you are making it a hundred times worse by forcing yourself to time these things. 

If I absolutely felt I had to place a time value on each exercise because insurance required it (Medicare does not and I don‚Äôt take other insurance so I haven‚Äôt seen that), I guess I would simply take my 25 minutes and arbitrarily break it up next to my list of exercises until it added up.  I wouldn‚Äôt even think about it.  I‚Äôd just say - let‚Äôs see there are 12 exercises here - 2 min each exercise and 3 min for one - done.  I would include ‚Äúrest time/transition time‚Äù with the exercise - we are human not robots.   Pretty sure BCBS isn‚Äôt going to challenge your time.

Rest breaks are part of the exercise. You are not billing just for the time they are actively moving. Education is also billable. All that time is part of your treatment. If you're with them and providing care you should be billing.

post_text:
I know none of us is a radiologist, but can anyone take a look at this and confirm or deny what I‚Äôm seeing? 

This is my husbands most recent lumbar MRI. He‚Äôs been dealing with moderate to debilitating pain with radicular symptoms to the left leg for almost 18 months now. Before the onset of pain he was swimming competitively 4-5x/wk and playing soccer 2x/wk, with general workouts including lifting (not heavy) and jogging several times weekly.  He was in excellent shape.  His symptoms are often all over the place (come and go with no real reason), range in locations (from mid back to foot and everywhere between, including intermittent saddle area sensations but no loss of bowel or bladder control), and frequently don‚Äôt make sense (several months ago he had extreme L QL pain to even light palpitation that caused immediate severe pain in the L knee and foot; when lying flat in prone or supine he can‚Äôt take a deep breath without feeling L foot pain or L butt pain depending on which direction his head is turned). I consider myself pretty smart, but I‚Äôve exhausted my knowledge base at this point. 

He‚Äôs had FIVE spinal specialists (including Mayo clinic in jacksonville) give opinions on his back, and almost all of them have said ‚Äúyeah L4/L5 and L5/S1 have mild to moderate disc bulging but its not that bad - just do PT or get an injection.‚Äù We were looking at his MRI today, and no one has EVER mentioned S2, but to me this looks like a pinch point.

I looked up S2 spinal compression and Tarlov cysts come up, but this looks like compression from the posterior side, not a cyst growth from the sacrum. 

Anyone have thoughts?

comments.text:
I am near Inverness Fl
I love a challenge
I also see the connection between the T/S, QL and pelvic floor;  he probably initially had a stiff t/s then injured the QL which led to muscle spam and doesn‚Äôt really have endurance in his deep core muscles 

I do a ton of manual and see great results- would be happy to help as i know how frustrating it is to have pain

Pelvic Floor Occupational Therapy; What is he doing for pain management? What is he doing for down regulating his nervous system? What is his work station like? What is he doing for exercise? Stretching? Is he constipated? How is this impacting his ADLs or lifestyle?

post_text: For those of you who treat out of a gym with excellent trainers.  How do you balance the exercise you do in PT with the gym activities they already perform.  I find myself educating on how to do things, the trainers and I talk, but I rarely have them do exercise in the office because it seems like overkill.   Asking because we're looking to expand and this is a question I have moving forward.  TIA

comments.text: I work at a clinic that sees a lot of fitness forward clients meaning they have a personal trainer, participate in boutique fitness, etc and I find these patients are typically the ones that need a lot of education on volume management and dosage. I spend a lot of time on programming for these patients, so maybe your time can be spent there. I also find these patients really benefit from a combination of manual therapy and neuro reeducation type exercises and/or exposure to different workout types like EMOM or AMRAP to vary the overall intensity of their workouts.

I usually have the patients do the PT exercises as accessory work/mobility work. If I know the main muscle groups are going to be hit in workouts i focus on the smaller muscles, motor control, mobility, specific tempos or range of motion, etc that aren't targeted in their workouts.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those of you who treat out of a gym with excellent trainers.  How do you balance the exercise you do in PT with the gym activities they already perform.  I find myself educating on how to do things, the trainers and I talk, but I rarely have them do exercise in the office because it seems like overkill.   Asking because we're looking to expand and this is a question I have moving forward.  TIA

COMMENT 1: I work at a clinic that sees a lot of fitness forward clients meaning they have a personal trainer, participate in boutique fitness, etc and I find these patients are typically the ones that need a lot of education on volume management and dosage. I spend a lot of time on programming for these patients, so maybe your time can be spent there. I also find these patients really benefit from a combination of manual therapy and neuro reeducation type exercises and/or exposure to different workout types like EMOM or AMRAP to vary the overall intensity of their workouts.

COMMENT 2: I usually have the patients do the PT exercises as accessory work/mobility work. If I know the main muscle groups are going to be hit in workouts i focus on the smaller muscles, motor control, mobility, specific tempos or range of motion, etc that aren't targeted in their workouts.

post_text: I need some ideas to increase flexion/scaption ROM after a reverse TSA. I have a patient who sustained a humerus fix during a snow skiing accident and required a subsequent reverse TSA. I suspect the pre-surgical trauma is slowing his progress  He‚Äôs 11wks S/P and still having significant pain‚Ä¶and his flexion ROM has been around 130 degrees for the last couple weeks. Clearly, I‚Äôm doing about 20 min of PROM and mobs twice weekly. His scap mobility is good.  It‚Äôs the glenihumeral joint and lats that seem stiff. Ultimately, I‚Äôd like to see him get about 150 deg flexion.  I appreciate any ideas.

comments.text: I'd stop trying to get more range. That's about as good as you are going to get a rTSA. He is probably in more pain because you are pushing the joint beyond what it should do. Work on mid range stability and correct muscle activation and he should continue to improve. I'd also do a lot of STM to the infra and teres muscles as well
A reverse TSA to 150 may not be a realistic goal

full_thread_text:
POST: I need some ideas to increase flexion/scaption ROM after a reverse TSA. I have a patient who sustained a humerus fix during a snow skiing accident and required a subsequent reverse TSA. I suspect the pre-surgical trauma is slowing his progress  He‚Äôs 11wks S/P and still having significant pain‚Ä¶and his flexion ROM has been around 130 degrees for the last couple weeks. Clearly, I‚Äôm doing about 20 min of PROM and mobs twice weekly. His scap mobility is good.  It‚Äôs the glenihumeral joint and lats that seem stiff. Ultimately, I‚Äôd like to see him get about 150 deg flexion.  I appreciate any ideas.

COMMENT 1: I'd stop trying to get more range. That's about as good as you are going to get a rTSA. He is probably in more pain because you are pushing the joint beyond what it should do. Work on mid range stability and correct muscle activation and he should continue to improve. I'd also do a lot of STM to the infra and teres muscles as well

COMMENT 2: A reverse TSA to 150 may not be a realistic goal

post_text: Question for my fellow sports orthopedic therapists. Do you have a court shoe recommendation for pickleball? She is wide width with mild midfoot pronation.

comments.text: New Balance, Brooks, Hoka, Asics just something she is comfortable in. Usually going shoe shopping when the feet are tired is good, and wear them around for 20 mins to determine how they feel if they are as supportive, and not rubbing anywhere. Some running stores have a treadmill inside the store to try them. Some pts we get from the podiatrist will get custom orthotics, it varies on if it helps, some take about 6 weeks. Usually a wear program few hours a day until they get used to the custom inserts. They could also get an over the counter set as needed.
I don't love Hokas for court sports since there is less lateral stability because of the rocker bottom. Those really are best only for walking and running.

full_thread_text:
POST: Question for my fellow sports orthopedic therapists. Do you have a court shoe recommendation for pickleball? She is wide width with mild midfoot pronation.

COMMENT 1: New Balance, Brooks, Hoka, Asics just something she is comfortable in. Usually going shoe shopping when the feet are tired is good, and wear them around for 20 mins to determine how they feel if they are as supportive, and not rubbing anywhere. Some running stores have a treadmill inside the store to try them. Some pts we get from the podiatrist will get custom orthotics, it varies on if it helps, some take about 6 weeks. Usually a wear program few hours a day until they get used to the custom inserts. They could also get an over the counter set as needed.

COMMENT 2: I don't love Hokas for court sports since there is less lateral stability because of the rocker bottom. Those really are best only for walking and running.

post_text: Ortho PT‚Äôs:  any advice on retraining VMO after months of atrophy and MPFL 5 weeks ago?  I have provided an NMES unit for daily use/HEP per protocol but minimal progress.

comments.text:
I don‚Äôt currently work in private practice but I have worked in D1 training rooms for quite some time, so this is actually very much my domain if you don‚Äôt mind me commenting here.

1) what e-stim machine are you using?AND What are the parameters you use using on the estim and what is the machine? Most portable machines (especially ones that can be purchased on Amazon) aren‚Äôt actually powerful enough to provide the kind of feedback to bounce back from true AMI after surgery unless meeting certain standards. Delaware produced a study not to long back looking at units and their ability to produce true motor recruitment. I have since switched to the Chattanooga portable unit (it‚Äôs about $400) and can be programmed for your patient and is a wonder!) I can forward this article. If you are using a non-portable Chattanooga device then try not using Russian estim setting, and instead trying utilizing symmetrical biphasic wavelength with 420+ phase duration and frequency of 55+ with cycle time of 10/50 for 15 mins. Still dial it up to reach borderline intolerable tetany. 

2) what are the size pads you are using? Wisconsin and a few other power 5s are utilizing 4x 8 inch pads and I got this tidbit about a year and half ago‚Äî I‚Äôll never go back. For my smaller patients I‚Äôll still never do smaller than 2x 4 inch pads. (Also noted in the Delaware study) the size of the pad allows you to recruit larger portions of all the muscles of the quadriceps and disperses the stim over a greater area allowing you to crank up the machine even higher and provide more electrical feedback. 

3) there is some recent research published as well on the utilization of ice specifically over the knee joint itself (basically just the patella and patellar and quad tendons and you can even put the same on the backside of knee joint) DO NOT GET ICE ON ANY SURROUNDING MUSCLE TISSUE (aka not on calves or quads) for about 10 mins immediately prior to activity. It shocks the joint proprioceptors to pay better attention to the joint motion and will decrease pain response which may be contributing to the AMI itself. 

I would try all of the above changes before ditching estim ‚Ä¶ anddd I would do all of this with quad sets so it‚Äôs not a difficult exercise when they are getting used to increased biofeedback/stimulation.(Estim should not be ditched before 80% LSI is achieved‚Äî which is much later in most rehabs than most people discontinue it‚Äî this is what OSU protocol indicates- there may even be an article I can find to support this)

Then‚Ä¶

4) TKE/SLR etc can all be cheated with muscles that work when you have AMI‚Äî I would switch to exercises that isolate (as much as possible the VMO) like SAQ AND ISO LAQ- although formerly believed to be taboo it‚Äôs extremely important to integrate E-stim with SAQ AND utilize E-stim with iso LAQ (belted at 60-90 deg‚Äî due to early precautions then progress) as quickly as possible in rehab (I have integrated it as early as 2 weeks post op given my patient is comfortable with 90deg flexi√≥n and min/no swelling)‚Äî estim with these two exercises specifically will help much more with the VMO (albeit the patient usually feels a bit uneasy about them‚Äî especially if it‚Äôs a quad tendon repair because they feel a bit of a tug)

your patient is 5 weeks post op so they should be able to tolerate both of these after changing parameters and pads with quad sets. The other commenters are right though MPFLs are much slower than an ACLR but you are right to be concerned. VMO activation should be back by week 6 at the very latest for probably good outcomes (not that it can‚Äôt happen‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs a longer bumpier road if not)

Happy to post the articles I referenced here (most of which are extrapolations from ACLR research) and I hope this helps!
To those of you who suggested BFR, what brand of device do you use and what training did you do?  (I‚Äôm mobile)

full_thread_text:
POST: Ortho PT‚Äôs:  any advice on retraining VMO after months of atrophy and MPFL 5 weeks ago?  I have provided an NMES unit for daily use/HEP per protocol but minimal progress.

COMMENT 1: I don‚Äôt currently work in private practice but I have worked in D1 training rooms for quite some time, so this is actually very much my domain if you don‚Äôt mind me commenting here.

1) what e-stim machine are you using?AND What are the parameters you use using on the estim and what is the machine? Most portable machines (especially ones that can be purchased on Amazon) aren‚Äôt actually powerful enough to provide the kind of feedback to bounce back from true AMI after surgery unless meeting certain standards. Delaware produced a study not to long back looking at units and their ability to produce true motor recruitment. I have since switched to the Chattanooga portable unit (it‚Äôs about $400) and can be programmed for your patient and is a wonder!) I can forward this article. If you are using a non-portable Chattanooga device then try not using Russian estim setting, and instead trying utilizing symmetrical biphasic wavelength with 420+ phase duration and frequency of 55+ with cycle time of 10/50 for 15 mins. Still dial it up to reach borderline intolerable tetany. 

2) what are the size pads you are using? Wisconsin and a few other power 5s are utilizing 4x 8 inch pads and I got this tidbit about a year and half ago‚Äî I‚Äôll never go back. For my smaller patients I‚Äôll still never do smaller than 2x 4 inch pads. (Also noted in the Delaware study) the size of the pad allows you to recruit larger portions of all the muscles of the quadriceps and disperses the stim over a greater area allowing you to crank up the machine even higher and provide more electrical feedback. 

3) there is some recent research published as well on the utilization of ice specifically over the knee joint itself (basically just the patella and patellar and quad tendons and you can even put the same on the backside of knee joint) DO NOT GET ICE ON ANY SURROUNDING MUSCLE TISSUE (aka not on calves or quads) for about 10 mins immediately prior to activity. It shocks the joint proprioceptors to pay better attention to the joint motion and will decrease pain response which may be contributing to the AMI itself. 

I would try all of the above changes before ditching estim ‚Ä¶ anddd I would do all of this with quad sets so it‚Äôs not a difficult exercise when they are getting used to increased biofeedback/stimulation.(Estim should not be ditched before 80% LSI is achieved‚Äî which is much later in most rehabs than most people discontinue it‚Äî this is what OSU protocol indicates- there may even be an article I can find to support this)

Then‚Ä¶

4) TKE/SLR etc can all be cheated with muscles that work when you have AMI‚Äî I would switch to exercises that isolate (as much as possible the VMO) like SAQ AND ISO LAQ- although formerly believed to be taboo it‚Äôs extremely important to integrate E-stim with SAQ AND utilize E-stim with iso LAQ (belted at 60-90 deg‚Äî due to early precautions then progress) as quickly as possible in rehab (I have integrated it as early as 2 weeks post op given my patient is comfortable with 90deg flexi√≥n and min/no swelling)‚Äî estim with these two exercises specifically will help much more with the VMO (albeit the patient usually feels a bit uneasy about them‚Äî especially if it‚Äôs a quad tendon repair because they feel a bit of a tug)

your patient is 5 weeks post op so they should be able to tolerate both of these after changing parameters and pads with quad sets. The other commenters are right though MPFLs are much slower than an ACLR but you are right to be concerned. VMO activation should be back by week 6 at the very latest for probably good outcomes (not that it can‚Äôt happen‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs a longer bumpier road if not)

Happy to post the articles I referenced here (most of which are extrapolations from ACLR research) and I hope this helps!

COMMENT 2: To those of you who suggested BFR, what brand of device do you use and what training did you do?  (I‚Äôm mobile)

post_text:
I‚Äôm a pelvic floor PT starting my private practice and also work PRN 1 day a week at a local hospital. I am the only PF PT at this hospital and sometimes see PF patients there, though most of my caseload is ortho. The rehab director has told me that this hospital system sends all PF referrals outside of the hospital, since there is no PF PT (other than me) to evaluate these patients. Today I got a call at my private practice (yay Google SEO) from a nurse who is with a gastroenterologist at the same hospital where I work prn. She asked if I treat a certain diagnosis and I said yes, so she sent me the referral. 

She doesn‚Äôt know I work there PRN 1 day a week and the hospital doesn‚Äôt know I have my own private practice. I have never marketed my private practice to patients at this hospital. 

My question is, when is this a conflict of interest and what should I do in regards to my prn job and also trying to market my private practice separately? Should I just quit my prn job so that no lines get blurred?

comments.text:
The hospital I was working at when starting my practice said there was no conflict due to my prn status. 

They congratulated me on my venture. 
 
Just ask your compliance department

The hospital could consider is a conflict of interest as it would be difficult for them to know you aren‚Äôt marketing your private business to hospital patients. I would disclose it, but you could lose the prn job. I do inpatient prn and they know about my pelvic floor PT but no conflict there because the inpatient patients wouldn‚Äôt be my private practice patients.

post_text:
Expert witness
Sooo, I work at a national outpatient business. I get a call from a law firm asking for an ex employee to sign an affidavit stating that all the PT treatment provided from a car accident was medically necessary. I share the employee is no longer there, they ask for another PT to sign it (and they changed the name on the form as the reviewer, kept that treatment was from original therapist). 

I ask, wouldn‚Äôt you have another uninvolved PT do this who isn‚Äôt within the company? I was told no, it doesn‚Äôt matter, just any PT. The person, paralegal I‚Äôm assuming, was trying to down play it like ‚Äúmost people just sign it haha‚Äù

So lemme ask: isn‚Äôt that a weak argument that the PT who treated would of course say treatment was medically necessary? And same, for a PT at the same company. 

Also- isn‚Äôt this thing supposed to be paid? $$$

***update: I looked at the eval and notes , they were poorly done with virtually no objective info, so I declined to sign. My compliance said they were gonna check to see what the balance was. They got back to me and only $110 balance so they were ok without me signing it. The paralegal never responded after I said I wouldn‚Äôt sign it üò¨. Soo, probably not reaching out to them for private witness statements lol

comments.text: ü§îü§îü§î

post_text:
Good morning!
I have a new patient who is with MC, but would like to come to my clinic for Dry Needling.  None of the in-network clinics in our area offer this service, and I believe either way it is a non-covered service by MC.

Any advice for how to go about providing her with this treatment, or any phrases that you use to CYA?  I am assuming phrasing it as wellness and Dry Needling?

So far I have no experience with "wellness," but just calling things physical therapy.  I know it's a fuzzy line that has been discussed here a lot.

Thank you so much in advance!

comments.text: For a while MC was covering acupuncture not sure if they are again/still are. I know it's not considered the same, but if they are on a budget. Some states DN is still grey or not covered with insurances. So the pt would be charged a fee for DN after a consent form was presented. More if they weren't already a patient. $30 vs $60. Adds up when they want multiples visits for the desired effect.
Google an abn form. Fill it out with section d. Dry needling. Should be good to go.

Thank you so much in advance!

COMMENT 1: For a while MC was covering acupuncture not sure if they are again/still are. I know it's not considered the same, but if they are on a budget. Some states DN is still grey or not covered with insurances. So the pt would be charged a fee for DN after a consent form was presented. More if they weren't already a patient. $30 vs $60. Adds up when they want multiples visits for the desired effect.

COMMENT 2: Google an abn form. Fill it out with section d. Dry needling. Should be good to go.

post_text: How did you deal with imposter syndrome at the beginning? I‚Äôm just starting my own business (have 5 years of PT experience)  and don‚Äôt feel like my services are worth charging prices I see on here for treatment/eval. I worry I don‚Äôt know enough/wont help my patients the same all on my own. Is this normal or am I not ready if I feel this way?

comments.text:
I started my company with less experience than you (1 year in my own business right now).  For whatever it's worth- I had similar concerns, so I did a lot of self reflection regarding what I'd treat. What conditions do you treat that you feel you can treat better than the average PT? Market your business towards that. Get a patient with a condition you don't feel confident in? Refer them elsewhere. That's what I did, helped me feel so much better being in business by myself. 

That being said, don't rest on only treating only things you like- identify your weaknesses and work on them. Take awesome continuing education courses - they are a business expense now too!

Something that helped me when I was in PT school was even if you don‚Äôt know everything you know more than your patient. Sometimes the simplest things make a huge difference in their life. Also, it gets better with experience (from the business and cash side). I used to feel guilty with a $150/hr charge but now I won‚Äôt accept less than $185 and might even consider raising those within the year. You get people who want to be there and get helped by you. You‚Äôre totally ready. Just be confident in what you do not and hold yourself responsible for what you don‚Äôt and keep learning. You got this!

post_text: What‚Äôs the hype around all these red light machines/beds? I‚Äôve noticed a lot of PT‚Äôs starting ‚Äúmed-spa‚Äù like treatment styles in their clinics

comments.text:
I have a unit in my clinic.   I have a small room/large closet size room that is perfect for it.
  Personally, I have chronic low back pain.  I will get on the table with the light for 20min in pain and have zero pain when I get off.   It‚Äôs extremely relaxing.   I was not expecting instant results but more benefits after routine sessions.  It was immediate results in my case.  
We have people use it for skin dermatitis, psoriasis with improved symptoms within 2-3 sessions.   I want to test it on neuropathy patients.

I have a Biomax panel and a stand that tilts horizontally so I can roll it on top of patient treatment areas with better proximity to the body.
I use a red light during session and if patient wants one I direct them in where to purchase. Very relaxing. I recommend reading and researching it more. It can be great for pain and inflammation.

Spinal Manipulation Institute (AAMT) has the DN-3 class which is specifically tailored to exactly what you are stating you want to know more about. Not only could you get some CEU‚Äôs, but the course is invaluable to clinicians and patients. I will be offering hands on services such as dry needling, IASTM, cupping-I don‚Äôt love the idea of offering these as stand alone ‚Äúa la carte‚Äù options though. The only manual I offer a la carte is dry needling and it is also 1 rate whether it takes 10 minutes or 30 minutes.

post_text:
Merry Christmas to those who celebrate!

If cost was not a factor, what is the absolute best knee brace for an adult in their 30s who likely has Ehlers-Danlos?

comments.text: I treat almost exclusively eds. I usually start with a compression sleeve. I find that braces can sometimes over correct and they're so mobile that a slight over can actually just push them the other way.  If that's not enough I've had good luck with the ACL braces (like don joy)

Futuro are my favorite. Target sells them. She can even try them on at target too before she buys. I give them to my professional athletes. They are sleek/not bulky yet supportive. I like the neoprene Velcro adjustable brace. They have a few different options for knee bracing but I like the discrete ones. The sleeves, I recommend those more for compression or lymphedema needs but people love the copper compression sleeves. I also specialize with hEDS in professional athletes and EDS in my private practice. I usually like something that maintains mobility but has great compressive support to reduce pain and discomfort.

full_thread_text:
POST: Merry Christmas to those who celebrate!

If cost was not a factor, what is the absolute best knee brace for an adult in their 30s who likely has Ehlers-Danlos?

COMMENT 1: I treat almost exclusively eds. I usually start with a compression sleeve. I find that braces can sometimes over correct and they're so mobile that a slight over can actually just push them the other way.  If that's not enough I've had good luck with the ACL braces (like don joy)

COMMENT 2: Futuro are my favorite. Target sells them. She can even try them on at target too before she buys. I give them to my professional athletes. They are sleek/not bulky yet supportive. I like the neoprene Velcro adjustable brace. They have a few different options for knee bracing but I like the discrete ones. The sleeves, I recommend those more for compression or lymphedema needs but people love the copper compression sleeves. I also specialize with hEDS in professional athletes and EDS in my private practice. I usually like something that maintains mobility but has great compressive support to reduce pain and discomfort.
