post_text: For PT‚Äôs who do diagnostic ultrasound. Do you charge separately for that? Do you offer those services to local sports teams if they need a quick ultrasound post injury to potentially diagnose something?

comments.text:
I charge as an adjunct to an initial evaluation. Do your ortho or rheum style exam to get a hypothesis list and use the most sensitive tests you can to whittle that list down. Once your list is more appropriate after the objective exam, add in the US for a specific exam with a write up of findings. 

If insurance that you are contracted with doesn‚Äôt cover it then charge separately. If you have your RMSK you should not be charging under $100 for that service.

If I had time I would offer to local sports teams, but all of my kids play sports and I‚Äôm always on the sideline with one of my portable units in case of an injury and they know it. It‚Äôs a helpful screening tool to determine necessity for PT and referrals.
Check your state practice act to confirm scope of practice.

full_thread_text:
POST: For PT‚Äôs who do diagnostic ultrasound. Do you charge separately for that? Do you offer those services to local sports teams if they need a quick ultrasound post injury to potentially diagnose something?

COMMENT 1: I charge as an adjunct to an initial evaluation. Do your ortho or rheum style exam to get a hypothesis list and use the most sensitive tests you can to whittle that list down. Once your list is more appropriate after the objective exam, add in the US for a specific exam with a write up of findings. 

If insurance that you are contracted with doesn‚Äôt cover it then charge separately. If you have your RMSK you should not be charging under $100 for that service.

If I had time I would offer to local sports teams, but all of my kids play sports and I‚Äôm always on the sideline with one of my portable units in case of an injury and they know it. It‚Äôs a helpful screening tool to determine necessity for PT and referrals.

COMMENT 2: Check your state practice act to confirm scope of practice.

post_text: I need expert advice from our pelvic floor PTs. There is a new FDA approved device called Osteoboost that is designed to improve bone density. It is a vibration therapy device that is worn 15 minutes per day. It will be available in February. Research is promising.  The only issue that may be of concern is how it might effect the pelvic floor. This is not my area of expertise.  So, I really need guidance.  TIA

comments.text:
So from the bit I read‚Ä¶ it seems a little far fetched. It doesn‚Äôt say it improves bone loss, it says it prevents it but the research shows there is still a reduction in bone density when using this device. 

When reading the research‚Ä¶ #1 it says it is not statistically significant. #2. There is still a reduction in bone loss. 
*for these reasons I would not recommend this device for bone density. Maybe for period cramps or something minor but not for bone density. 

The sad thing is, if these women got on a treadmill or elliptical or something for three days a week, for a whole year, they would likely have greater results than this vibration belt. 

I‚Äôm a pelvic floor OT. Have a ton of experience with vibration plates for athletes, people in wheelchairs, and children. However, I haven‚Äôt seen it marketed to increase bone density. 

Just curious what makes you think it could affect the pelvic floor? It seems like it may be a good relaxation device that could help with pelvic floor discomfort. I usually recommend the hypervolt back brace that has vibration and infraredÔøº heat.

It‚Äôs only approved per research on people with osteopenia if the lumbar spine. It‚Äôs a $$$ making toy. Osteopenia and osteoporosis is systemic.  The whole skeletal system is affected. We have far better evidence for exercise than this gimmick. I do not recommend this device to my clients.  Ôøº

post_text: Wanting to get some opinions. I'm a male therapist who is the only employee in my new clinic. I treat a wide variety of people, but the demographic that brings up my question is the female minors I see that are not accompanied by a parent. If I plan to do any manual I do request that somebody else accompany that patient to their appointment.  I can't imagine any scenario where anything would show up but wandering thought got the best of me.  In a CYA mindset, is it appropriate to have camera monitoring on full time just in case anything was to arise? Is that legal? Would I have to have each patient/guardian sign an informed consent etc? Thank you for your input.

comments.text: Honestly, I wonder about anyone treating a person of any age, alone in an office.

Leave the door open, have patient come in gym clothes and definitely have a female staffer nearby. I don't know where you are located but treating extremities seem less risky than thoracic or lumbosacral/pelvic/hip/ SI treatments. The clinic should cover you but you want to be as transparant as possible. I'm sorry this is the world we live in.

post_text:
For those who treat chronic pain:

What does your Perfect Patient Plan look like?

I feel I will need to modify compared to my regular MSK patients.

comments.text: It involves a lot of pain neuroscience education

Not sure about a ‚Äúperfect patient plan‚Äù as I‚Äôm not familiar with that phrase. 

I use trauma neuroscience as a method to address the root cause of the symptoms. I focus on increasing specificity of interoceptive awareness of the specific tissues involved. I also help the patient create internal safety/stability so the brain can finally process the innate memory that contributed to the altered interoceptive awareness and limited processing from involved tissues the first place. 

Ideally patient will experience significant changes after each visit while simultaneously increasing their sense of internal safety and stability. This leads to a larger window of tolerance, resolution of pain, and significantly less recurrence of symptoms.

post_text: Hey all. I have a severe thoracic outlet case who is awaiting thoracic surgeon appointment. Long hx of pain and has been in and out of PT for 2 years with some relief but nothing long lasting. It appears to be true vascular compression. I am trying to alleviate some of her symptoms leading up to the appointment. Are there any unique go to techniques you all have found helpful in these cases? TIA!

comments.text: Muscle energy technique and even SCS have powerful techniques for  TOS..

Check for hypermobility at the shoulder as well. My best friend from PT school had an unrelenting case of thoracic outlet and also scores a 7-8 on the Beighton scale (I forget her exact score). Whenever she would carry things, the traction on her shoulder was contributing significantly to her TOS. She was able to largely resolve her symptoms with a lot of work on shoulder stabilization. She also did a lot of work to improve her awareness so she could rely more on active vs passive support of the shoulder, especially with lifting/carrying.

post_text:
What is your favorite patient rejection reason of the year?

Got my first "They don't want you back" rejection of 2024 (that I know of). The patient had hip surgery and is coming home. The daughter told my friend that "My PTA and I talked too much and didn't do enough work." 

Umm, that's because we were trying to talk them into doing the basics that would prevent them from needing surgery in the first place.

comments.text:
I had a notoriously difficult pt (OP sports) who really wanted her problem to be that she was tight rather than weak ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è She resisted strengthening even though she really wanted to get back to tennis, so I tried to blend some stretching with a lot of education and gradual increase on the strengthening exercises. Eventually she came in and said:

"This isn't working. I don't come in here for YOUR EMPATHY."

ü§ØüòÇ

Ok, pal. You go on with your bad self. Wish you all the luck in the world.

Unpopular opinion...
Perception is reality is tough to hear. Even if you are right, it didn't come across to the client in a way they could, or were willing to understand.  It's our choice if we want to Self improve so we can reach those difficult ones, or just stick to the easy ones. 
Sometimes,  it just won't work, and that's OK too. But after 32 years of practicing,  most of the time I can get my message across and they can benefit.  If not, refer out to someone else they may "hear" better from.

post_text: Hi all I had a question for anyone who has worked with private schools in the past. I was approached with an opportunity and asked to work with a local school working at some of their games being more of an athletic trainer, but also providing some physical therapy skills in terms of working with coaches and student athletes on rehab exercises following injury. The athletic director asked me to send over what my hourly rate would be so that they could talk to their school administration about it and I need help because I really want this position but don‚Äôt want to undervalue my services. Has anyone worked in this scenario before and what was a fair price to charge. Ôøº

comments.text: I would be very cautious to practice within your scope of practice. In PA, PTs have lost their license because of practicing as a ATC.  You need to be a ‚Äúfirst responder ‚Äú and be certified in emergency care as a minimum.  Lots of liability issues. My company has many school contracts but we use ATCs (then PTs as needed for post injury treatment ). We also have PTs but they are ATCs too.

Thank you for the input on this! I‚Äôm in Colorado and I had told the AD that I wanted to look into the state laws as to what I can and cannot do and specified that I was not an athletic trainer but rather a PT but that were allowed to do splinting/ taping ankles, assess concussion, and assess acute injury as well as give ice for injuries etc

post_text:
Anybody had good luck with applying estim or Russian estim to the medial quad to get it to activate for a pt post PCA stroke (minimal impact) and post TKA about 8 months ago? 
I have a pt in home health who is in 60s and still got life goals to meet but can‚Äôt walk steady and demonstrates knee valgus. Atrophy is noted on the medial side of quad. Anybody have better suggestions? 
Would greatly appreciate.

comments.text:
We just purchased a Bioness quadricep e-stim unit. It works the same as the foot drop model with a gyroscope the patient uses.  Every time they heel strike it kicks on.  

It is very high in price but they do work with the VA and get them covered for patients.  

If you follow the same concept, regular NMES would be the same.
If the issue is valgum, medial knee strengthening is probably not where you need to be focusing. I‚Äôd switch gears and look hard at the glute max and femoral external rotators.

If you follow the same concept, regular NMES would be the same.

post_text: Does it state anywhere in Medicare guidelines a specific frequency for maintenance therapy? Have a couple patients with Parkinson‚Äôs who have plateaued but would like to cont to see them 2 times per week

comments.text: I just document as much as I can and reduce frequency gradually. As frequency changes I make sure to repeatedly test functional measures to assess for a decline in function and other risks like hospitalization, pressure sores, potential for increased level of care needs, and falls based on gait speed and other tests (4 square step test, DGI, TUG, ect). Also documenting caregiver training and feedback from caregivers on what they‚Äôre observing in function and concerns.

full_thread_text:
POST: Does it state anywhere in Medicare guidelines a specific frequency for maintenance therapy? Have a couple patients with Parkinson‚Äôs who have plateaued but would like to cont to see them 2 times per week

COMMENT 1: I just document as much as I can and reduce frequency gradually. As frequency changes I make sure to repeatedly test functional measures to assess for a decline in function and other risks like hospitalization, pressure sores, potential for increased level of care needs, and falls based on gait speed and other tests (4 square step test, DGI, TUG, ect). Also documenting caregiver training and feedback from caregivers on what they‚Äôre observing in function and concerns.

post_text:
Just started my own cash based practice in Richmond, VA but still trying to figure out my niche as I find clients. I have a personal training background before becoming a PT and I work outpatient and SNF currently (both per diem). 

I‚Äôve been thinking of taking some courses to specialize in something to set me apart. My two thoughts have been pelvic floor and TMJ. Anyone work specifically in these areas and have recommendations or input on con ed to get started?

comments.text:
My advice would be to only enter a specialty if you're passionate about it, not because you think it will get you clients. As a pelvic floor therapist, you have to be knowledgeable about pregnancy/postpartum/reproductive care, gastroenterology, urogynecology, menopause, etc. so one or two courses is not going to cut it, it's a lifetime of learning!
That being said, we were all beginners at one point so if you are truly passionate, you'll want to start with Pelvic Health Level 1 through either the APTA or Herman & Wallace. But just know that it doesn't stop there and you will need to continue to take many, many courses to truly excel as a pelvic floor therapist as there's so much about this specialty we don't learn in school.
Hi Jazlyn! Your personal training background can be a great way to set you apart! I agree with Rachel's recommendation to only enter a specialty if you're passionate about it.

full_thread_text:

I‚Äôve been thinking of taking some courses to specialize in something to set me apart. My two thoughts have been pelvic floor and TMJ. Anyone work specifically in these areas and have recommendations or input on con ed to get started?

COMMENT 1: My advice would be to only enter a specialty if you're passionate about it, not because you think it will get you clients. As a pelvic floor therapist, you have to be knowledgeable about pregnancy/postpartum/reproductive care, gastroenterology, urogynecology, menopause, etc. so one or two courses is not going to cut it, it's a lifetime of learning!
That being said, we were all beginners at one point so if you are truly passionate, you'll want to start with Pelvic Health Level 1 through either the APTA or Herman & Wallace. But just know that it doesn't stop there and you will need to continue to take many, many courses to truly excel as a pelvic floor therapist as there's so much about this specialty we don't learn in school.

COMMENT 2: Hi Jazlyn! Your personal training background can be a great way to set you apart! I agree with Rachel's recommendation to only enter a specialty if you're passionate about it.

post_text: I‚Äôm a mobile cash based PT who specializes in concussion. I was contacted by an athletic trainer at a local high school who asked if I‚Äôd be willing to see kids there at their training room. I don‚Äôt see why not‚ÄîI have no location listed on my insurance because I don‚Äôt have a clinic, and travel to peoples homes. Any insurance considerations here that I might be missing?

comments.text: I do that as part of my full time job (have a side cash practice) but my full time job has a contract with the high school and my employer pays for this. Other clinics in our area do it on different days, but I'm pretty sure they do it as a write off (I'm sure mine does as well). I would want to know who paying for it and the liability coverage. The other thing is many are minors, so any sort of consent to treat would be important to cover. Parents of athletes can be difficult. The athletes are typically awesome to work with and a fun environment overall, but some things to consider

List them as an additional
Insured on your policy. Make sure your policy covers services there.

post_text: What to do on personal trainers promoting ‚Äúbalance training‚Äù for people? I feel like that is not in their scope of practice. How would you all combat this? Their website is basically promoting physical therapy and saying they work with people who are ‚Äúrecovering from illnesses or injuries.‚Äù

comments.text: As long as they are not stating that they treat illness its perfectly fine for them to do training balance etc. The difference is we treat they don't.

You guys would be surprised at what personal trainers are capable of. They have a lot less restrictions on them than we do. A lot of them are now receiving training on "corrective exercise", which overlaps greatly with what we do. As someone who consumes a lot of content on Instagram and YouTube from both physical therapists and personal trainers, I will tell you that there are some amazing personal trainers out there.

I've seen personal trainers provide exercises to help with balance. I do not feel that it is out of their scope. But to treat a diagnosed balance dysfunction is where the differences arise in our training . But guess what, they can do it anyway and no one can do anything about it.  

They can practice across state lines, they don't need a physician to sign a plan of care, they don't even need to worry about their state practice act because there is not one as far as I know. If I'm wrong correct me on this. 
And they can treat Medicare patients until the cows come home and charge whatever they want. PT on the other hand,  a totally different story.

post_text: Had a concierge doc call me today to go do an evaluation for someone getting outpatient PT, but wants more at her home. She also wants me to do a home assessment for her. Used ChatGPT to give me an Ada compliant form so I would know what to check and make a form to fill out for fall assessment so I can give it to her. Going to find a local handyman to refer to if she needs home modifications.  This is something I have been thinking about doing, but no promoting it.

comments.text: Jeremy Sutton let me know if you need our Home Modifications/Environmental Assessment form. I will email it to you.

That's fantastic that you're looking to support your patient with a home assessment! Ensuring safety at home is so important for promoting independence and reducing fall risks.

As an OT who specializes in conducting comprehensive home evaluations and recommending personalized modifications. Our training focuses on how individuals interact with their environment during daily activities, considering both physical and cognitive aspects.

There's substantial evidence supporting OT-led home modifications in improving patient outcomes. Collaborating with an OT could enhance the support you're providing and ensure your patient receives the most effective care.

post_text: What is the general view of using manual muscle tests as an objective measure of progress? Our clinic is trying to steer few of us veterans away from using manual muscle tests and it feels like they just don't want to go through the hassle of doing them. I feel like they are really easy to do and can be measurable goals. They are also indicating that there's not enough inter-rater reliability, but that actually means to me that they require more skills in this area as opposed to me needing to simply use the manual muscle test less. Please give me your thoughts all for or opposed.

comments.text:
Research proves they're unreliable and they're not objective at all once you get higher than 3 where the strength becomes subjective based on the rater and proper stabilization and positioning. 
I think they can be helpful for low level patients but functional measures like STS and TUG are much more objective, repeatable, reliable and obviously functional.

There‚Äôs no harm in doing it. If you don‚Äôt want to use it for goal setting then fine, but it takes 2 seconds to perform and the patient also gets feedback about how their body is performing. Our profession is ridiculous when it comes to this stuff. If you don‚Äôt want to use it then don‚Äôt, but don‚Äôt go telling other not to do it because it does provide beneficial information when used in the grand scheme of an evaluation. I wouldn‚Äôt stop using them Janell Klosterman to influence your exam findings, but may choose to use other measures for goal setting based on insurance practices

post_text: Many of us are trying to operate in a coaching or educational capacity without establishing a patient-clinician relationship.  From a legal standpoint, are there things or language you can use to protect yourself and not accidentally cross the line?

comments.text:
I am taking a page from Mike Chua's methodology. Here is what ChatGPT said:
...
Operating in a coaching or educational capacity without establishing a patient-clinician relationship is becoming increasingly common, but it does require clear boundaries to avoid legal issues. Here are some strategies and specific language that you can use to protect yourself and ensure you're not crossing the line into providing medical care:

1. Disclaimers
Clearly state that your services are educational or coaching in nature, and not intended as a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Use disclaimers prominently on your website, in written materials, and at the beginning of your sessions. Example disclaimer:

"Disclaimer: The information provided during this session is for educational and informational purposes only and does not constitute medical advice or a patient-provider relationship. Please consult your healthcare provider before making any changes to your health or exercise routine."
2. Language to Avoid & Alternative Phrasing
Avoid language that implies direct care or treatment. Refrain from using terms like "treatment," "prescription," "therapy," or "diagnosis." Instead, use terms like:

"General guidance," "educational information," "suggestions," "best practices," or "insights."
For example:

Instead of: "I recommend you perform these exercises."
Use: "These exercises are commonly used for people experiencing similar symptoms, but please discuss this with your healthcare provider to determine if they're right for you."
3. Clarify Your Role
Make it clear that you are acting as a coach or educator, not a healthcare provider in this context. Examples:

"I am providing this information as a coach/educator, not as a healthcare provider."
"Our interaction today is intended to provide general information and education, and does not establish a clinical relationship."
4. Encourage Seeking Medical Advice
Always direct individuals to seek personal medical advice from their healthcare provider for specific questions or issues:

"Please consult with your physician or healthcare provider before implementing any changes or if you have specific concerns about your condition."
5. Avoid Providing Individualized Treatment Plans
Avoid crafting specific treatment plans or exercises tailored to an individual‚Äôs specific condition without an assessment, as this could be interpreted as practicing physical therapy. Instead, focus on providing generalized information:

Instead of: "Based on your symptoms, you should do these exercises."
Use: "These are some common exercises that people find helpful for this type of issue. Please discuss them with your provider to determine if they are suitable for you."
6. Document Everything
If you are operating online, maintain records of any interactions and ensure that disclaimers are present in emails, websites, or any digital communications. This documentation can be valuable in showing your intent and the nature of the relationship.

7. Terms of Use Agreement
If you have a website or provide online courses, create a Terms of Use Agreement that participants must accept. This should outline:

The nature of the relationship (educational vs. therapeutic).
Clear disclaimers of liability.
Limitations of your services.
8. Consent for Coaching Sessions
If you provide one-on-one coaching, get explicit consent from the individual, acknowledging that:

"This session is for educational purposes only, and no patient-clinician relationship is being established."
Having them sign a consent form helps protect both parties and establishes boundaries.

9. Understand Scope of Practice Laws
Different states or regions have different laws about what is allowed without a license. Make sure to review local regulations regarding your professional capacity, especially as a physical therapist. For example, the use of certain titles (like "Physical Therapist") can imply a clinical relationship, which could create liability issues. Instead, you could use titles such as "Health Coach" or "Wellness Educator" for clarity.

These measures can help ensure you stay within the bounds of providing coaching or educational services without crossing into clinical practice, reducing legal risks while still providing value to your audience.

Yea you need to be clear and have a waiver or disclaimer, but the question is ‚Äúwill it stand up in court?‚ÄùAnyone wanting to sue you will go for your highest license because it means a bigger settlement. I would look into consulting insurance from a local commercial insurance rep to protect you there. PTs absolutely consult, but if you are educating individually on how to help themselves, it‚Äôs a blurry line (vs assisting with a company‚Äôs injury prevention plan, or teaching a class).

Hire a good lawyer, make it clear you aren‚Äôt providing treatment (not a bad idea to have documentation for sessions to show you didn‚Äôt provide treatment), but it‚Äôs tough. Like imagine a surgeon opening a nutrition business and then a person goes into diabetic shock.  You better believe that lawyer is going after his medical license. If the surgeon documented what happened each session showing he didn‚Äôt advise sugar and the patient signed a waiver acknowledging it wasn‚Äôt medical advice then at least the surgeon has a chance in court.

post_text: We have family friends whose 11 yo son experienced a traumatic brain injury. They‚Äôre looking for a good outpatient neuro program. Any recommendations? Or do any of you go into homes with a lot of experience with traumatic brain injuries? He‚Äôs going to need speech, PT and OT. ÔøºThey are in the Allen/Fairview/Lucas area.

comments.text: I am assuming if he is ready for outpatient then he already has completed an intense rehab program?  If not, and this is an acute injury and the acute care hospital is discharging him straight home then I would start with an intense inpatient rehab program that would include 3 hours of therapy each day.  Shriners in Northern California has a TBI program but I‚Äôm not sure if Shriners in Galveston, TX does too.  They can certainly get accepted to the program in Northern California if it is the closest, just need a physician to send referral and they accept regardless of insurance or ability to pay.  If they have already done inpatient rehab then the social worker and the staff should be able to provide referrals for the immediate area.  Plus most states have programs for kids, here in California it is called California Children‚Äôs Services and it provides therapies and equipment for children with disabilities congenital or acquired.
Pate Rehab & CNS (Centre for Neuro Skills) are top Neuro centers in DFW. I'm not sure what percentage is pediatric, but I'd definitely start researching those. They both offer Day Neuro Programs.

full_thread_text:
POST: We have family friends whose 11 yo son experienced a traumatic brain injury. They‚Äôre looking for a good outpatient neuro program. Any recommendations? Or do any of you go into homes with a lot of experience with traumatic brain injuries? He‚Äôs going to need speech, PT and OT. ÔøºThey are in the Allen/Fairview/Lucas area.

COMMENT 1: I am assuming if he is ready for outpatient then he already has completed an intense rehab program?  If not, and this is an acute injury and the acute care hospital is discharging him straight home then I would start with an intense inpatient rehab program that would include 3 hours of therapy each day.  Shriners in Northern California has a TBI program but I‚Äôm not sure if Shriners in Galveston, TX does too.  They can certainly get accepted to the program in Northern California if it is the closest, just need a physician to send referral and they accept regardless of insurance or ability to pay.  If they have already done inpatient rehab then the social worker and the staff should be able to provide referrals for the immediate area.  Plus most states have programs for kids, here in California it is called California Children‚Äôs Services and it provides therapies and equipment for children with disabilities congenital or acquired.

COMMENT 2: Pate Rehab & CNS (Centre for Neuro Skills) are top Neuro centers in DFW. I'm not sure what percentage is pediatric, but I'd definitely start researching those. They both offer Day Neuro Programs.

post_text: Hi all, does anyone happen to know if with telehealth (e.g. on the Jane App), are we allowed to treat anyone in the U.S. even if we are licensed in 1 state? E.g. If I am licensed in Hawai'i, can I treat patients who move to or live in California, Washington, Utah, etc? Much appreciated üôè.

comments.text: My understanding is wellness yes but physical therapy skilled treatment based services you need to be licensed within the state you are providing those services whether teletherapy or in person. Each state has different laws and regulations
My understanding is as a licensed PT, OT, SLP you can only treat in person or via telehealth in the state you are licensed in

post_text: Question for those of you who work with athletes:  The parents of my daughter‚Äôs select soccer team (11 year olds) want advice on hydration and electrolyte drinks.  I want to make sure I give them the latest research but finding conflicting info, especially regarding when/how much sports drink to consume.  They are about to start boot camp/scrimmages in triple digit Texas heat.  Last season, I think there was an excess of orange Powerade consumption (ü§¢üòâ)‚Ä¶What guidance would you give?

comments.text:
I would recommend LMNT! Definitely very salty, but it‚Äôs the cleanest I have found! I give to my 7 and 14 yr olds who play sports! I water it down‚Ä¶use 1/2 packets in their 32 oz bottles!
Also use Ultima (not as clean, but waaaayyy better than Gatorade/Powerade, etc) and you can get these packers on Amazon and local health food stores! Variety of flavors as well!

I don't work with athletes in this capacity, but a Liquid IV packet once or twice a day (and water the rest of the time) works really well. Learned about it from my granddad's cancer battle, when he kept getting dehydrated so easily.

post_text:
Next summer I plan to get certified in Dry Needling. I am in Central Wisconsin and am cash/ non-insurance based PT and wellness. Does anyone have any recommendations on pricing for dry needling services ? I‚Äôm in the preliminary phases obviously but I am a planner at heart and want to get an eyeball on things if and when possible. Any help is appreciated! Also, if anyone has suggestions on which dry needling training y‚Äôall used, that would also be appreciated. 
I am a GCS and LSVT-BIG certified as well.

comments.text:
I like Rachel Garrett‚Äôs thoughts. I also have had sessions where the only thing performed was dry needling, and I charged my full rate. 

What‚Äôs important, Christian Biegel, is that (all of us) must get away from ‚Äúa CPT code value‚Äù for a service (yes, I know. Dry needling isn‚Äôt covered, but the concept of ‚Äúthis thing is worth this amount‚Äù). Instead, we should recognize that people are paying for our knowledge, skill, experience, etc. 

Scott Dixon has a phenomenal course.  There are several others out there also.

I have a cash pay practice in Oshkosh and regularly utilize DN with my patients. I do not charge an additional fee if DN is used as a part of a full PT session. I do offer a mini-session for clients with an established POC who just need DN or manual therapy. After a full evaluation session, I offer appropriate clients the mini session for $75

post_text:
I have a friend in late 50s that has L sided neck pain. Has tried both conventional PT (with another clinic) which included dry needling.  Still has significant pain with turning his head to the L. Imaging reported significant spondylosis. Was going to have surgery, but surgeon then reported that he does not think it will help. They are on multiple medications to help manage pain but despite these medications, he still cannot turn his head to the L and is in a constant state of pain. 
Any other suggestions that I can offer to this person for pain management? TIA!

comments.text:
Need more info regarding physical assessment. What is the suspected pain generator and what were positive special tests? Are there radicular symptoms and/or involvement of the shoulder? Also wondering if part of your post got left out - what other interventions have been tried thus far beyond DN? 

Agree with above regarding facet assessment/mobilization, facilitation. Should also check upper thoracic rotation and 1st rib mobility. 

Regarding the DN and any other manual intervention, not worth much of not followed by active intervention. If all has been assessed and appropriate intervention performed, may look at pain psych. Wondering the timeline of all this as well.

How much ROM does he have to the L?‚Ä¶I usually let that guide my treatment (upper, mid, lower cervical)‚Ä¶mulligan mobs with movement can be very helpful bc then you can teach them to self mob= more carryover.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a friend in late 50s that has L sided neck pain. Has tried both conventional PT (with another clinic) which included dry needling.  Still has significant pain with turning his head to the L. Imaging reported significant spondylosis. Was going to have surgery, but surgeon then reported that he does not think it will help. They are on multiple medications to help manage pain but despite these medications, he still cannot turn his head to the L and is in a constant state of pain. 
Any other suggestions that I can offer to this person for pain management? TIA!

COMMENT 1: Need more info regarding physical assessment. What is the suspected pain generator and what were positive special tests? Are there radicular symptoms and/or involvement of the shoulder? Also wondering if part of your post got left out - what other interventions have been tried thus far beyond DN? 

Agree with above regarding facet assessment/mobilization, facilitation. Should also check upper thoracic rotation and 1st rib mobility. 

Regarding the DN and any other manual intervention, not worth much of not followed by active intervention. If all has been assessed and appropriate intervention performed, may look at pain psych. Wondering the timeline of all this as well.

COMMENT 2: How much ROM does he have to the L?‚Ä¶I usually let that guide my treatment (upper, mid, lower cervical)‚Ä¶mulligan mobs with movement can be very helpful bc then you can teach them to self mob= more carryover.

post_text:
What‚Äôs the youngest age you have dry needled someone?

Have a 10 year old kid with classic IT band syndrome. Very very very active kid. Plays 5 different sports. Very athletic.

comments.text: I‚Äôm sure you know this and will address but for the sake of anyone else who needs to hear it I think we are missing the picture here! A 10 year old playing 5 sports. Missed opportunity if we don‚Äôt pause and educate the parents and the child and give them the valuable opportunity to give their body a rest to heal. Regardless of needling. Emotionally and physically this is hard on the body at 10. We are in a unique position to have these conversations and help possibly change the trajectory moving forward for this child. Probably not, but we must try to promote some balance and help children at a young age pay attention to their bodies in a good way! Good luck with that conversation and remember we got people better before needling was a thing. Maybe at a young age we go old school?
9 year old gymnast with both mom and child on board

full_thread_text:

post_text:
Have a post op ACL patient I‚Äôve been seeing. He‚Äôs about to be 5 weeks out.

In my mind he‚Äôs doing great. Were able to do blazepods for balance and hip strengthening. We do BFR for short arc quads, straight leg raise, and hip abduction in supine.

He definitely does a lot of exercises at home so I‚Äôm not sitting here doing all the basic heel slide/quad set exercises so we can focus on the big stuff that he can‚Äôt do at home.

He had his appointment with the surgeon yesterday and he was not happy at all and told the patient he may have some permanent limitations because his range of motion wasn‚Äôt 100% yet.

Patient is a big hypochondriac and is freaking out. So I tried reassuring him that according to our protocol we are doing fine and to not worry. And I told him at the start of 5 weeks we‚Äôd be doing a lot more such as leg press/mini squats and really start working on the knee itself as far as range of motion.

Any advice from anyone?

comments.text:
Don‚Äôt assume what he heard is what was said. 

Trust your gut. 

Unless you are in the room at the follow up visit what he thinks he heard is likely only the voice in his head.
What‚Äôs the range of motion actively & passively?

post_text:
Hey guyys, i've seen some people talk about this, but honestly I don't know how I feel about it. I have a PT I work with that's COMT certified and his treatment methods are very different to McKenzie methods. Ive seen  posts where is has  been mostly COMT PT's bashing MDT PT's but honestly I'm trying to see where they find Maitland methods to be better.
A lot of the good McKenzie therapists, does not see this as "everyone does extension, they get better." They see it as a diagnostic tool. There has been several patients in my career that have been not extension responders but have been even
flexion or rotational movements. We over flex as a society given that functional activities are in some form of flexion mostly. That's why I think most people respond best to extension because we over flex which cause changes in the spine/discs.
For those who have had both Mckenzie training and Maitland training what do you feel is a more ideal method to diagnose and treat patients?
Also, do you find one method or the other to be better for different pathologies?

comments.text: No one should be bashing any one style. The reality is, they all help for the right patients. Some patients will respond better to Maitland, others to Mckenzie, others to [insert other style]. Your job as a PT is to have as many tools in the toolbox as possible so that when you come across a patient, you can not only fit them into the right style but the right technique in that style. Not everyone is a Mckenzie patient. And that's ok. I do a lot of counterstrain- and not everyone is a counterstrain patient, and that's ok.

I‚Äôm Maitland certified and I think it‚Äôs appalling that any PT is bashing another technique.  
I think the best PTs are the ones with lots of varying tools available to them.
At its core, Maitland is an assessment approach (not a treatment technique).  The accessory mobility assessment does often lead to treatment (ie. Mobilizations) but in actuality I find the treatment often aligns with preferential directional treatment (which I believe falls under the McKenzie theories).

I‚Äôm not McKenzie trained, but I have worked with McKenzie therapists‚Ä¶ and I think the two approaches actually blend quite well together.

post_text:
I want to feel out the Uncaged community on a business idea I have. I am a physical therapist and have 16 years experience, with the last 11.5 years being in home health with a mostly geriatric population. In my work with senior patients, I find that most of them won‚Äôt keep up with their exercise routine after I discharge. I get it. It‚Äôs really hard to start and stick with an exercise routine when no one is holding you accountable. But when they don‚Äôt keep up their exercises, they usually lose the progress they made with me and end up weaker, often falling and breaking something, at which point they‚Äôre referred back for therapy again and we start back at square one (or even further back). I wish insurance companies would pay for regular, ongoing therapy visits to prevent this kind of decline, but the reality is that they just don‚Äôt. The patients I treat are homebound, so going to an outpatient clinic usually isn‚Äôt an option. Mobile therapy options that bill as outpatient are also limited (my sister actually had her own practice doing this but recently moved out of state, and I have no desire to deal with the insurance headache that she had to, all for minimal reimbursement).

So here is my idea. To have a business that offers only wellness visits to seniors. No skilled physical therapy service, which means it is not billed to insurance and does not require a plan of care. It would be private pay only with visits as often as the client wants. Almost like having a personal trainer come to the home but with the knowledge and training of a physical therapist. The goal would be to assist clients in performing their home exercises and establishing an overall wellness routine, while also being able to monitor patients for red flags that their doctor may need to know about (like signs of infection, high blood pressure, low oxygen, etc) in order to prevent avoidable hospitalizations. Does anyone here have a practice like this? Is this a service you think you, your parents, or your grandparents would use? I have such a passion for helping the senior community to improve their health and prevent (or at least slow down) any avoidable decline, so I‚Äôm brainstorming ways I can make that happen. ‚ò∫Ô∏è (I know this was long‚Ä¶thanks for reading!)

comments.text: I am doing this now.  I‚Äôm a certified personal trainer as well as a physical therapist. There is a huge need when I discharge people from Home Health physical therapy to continue with the wellness program. This works great.  I do carry malpractice insurance on my business. I also make them sign a consent form stating that they are receiving Personal Training and not Physical THERAPY in order to cover myself.  Another thing I do is work with Luna, which is a company owned by a physical therapist who does all the backend billing. Once the patient is discharged from Home Health I picked them up as an outpatient physical therapy. The company does all the insurance billing authorization and calling the doctors. Once that‚Äôs completed I offer wellness packages.  Ôøº

One thought I had about marketing would be to take this to the local ALF‚Äôs/ILF‚Äôs. There are several in my area. Yeah those places may have daily exercise classes, but in my experience, not many residents take advantage of those classes. Partly due to laziness (don‚Äôt want to leave their room) or partly due to not wanting others to see them doing exercises in case they can‚Äôt keep up. Others just aren‚Äôt motivated at all, which would likely translate to not being motivated to take what I can offer either, in which case they‚Äôre not my target client.

Another thing I do is work with Luna, which is a company owned by a physical therapist who does all the backend billing. Once the patient is discharged from Home Health I picked them up as an outpatient physical therapy. The company does all the insurance billing authorization and calling the doctors. Once that‚Äôs completed I offer wellness packages.  Ôøº

COMMENT 2: One thought I had about marketing would be to take this to the local ALF‚Äôs/ILF‚Äôs. There are several in my area. Yeah those places may have daily exercise classes, but in my experience, not many residents take advantage of those classes. Partly due to laziness (don‚Äôt want to leave their room) or partly due to not wanting others to see them doing exercises in case they can‚Äôt keep up. Others just aren‚Äôt motivated at all, which would likely translate to not being motivated to take what I can offer either, in which case they‚Äôre not my target client.

post_text:
I launched my cash-practice 11 weeks ago!!

I am practicing out of a sports performance gym and treating athletes/active individuals. I am working the kinks out and optimizing systems‚Ä¶ the joys of business ownership lol. 

My question is, in relation to direct access/legalities/ethics what am I missing when it comes to true ‚ÄúPT POC‚Äù vs wellness programming and treatments? Practicing in Louisiana (for reference) Direct Access laws are very open and direct. 

I‚Äôm in an environment where clients have issues but not really injuries. So, trying to figure out the optimal way to create a treatment plan/program to meet their needs and my bottom line. ANY thoughts would be more than helpful. Love this group of people, thank you in advance!!

comments.text: I‚Äôm five years into my cash based practice in TN, and despite my best efforts, I cannot find a clear answer to this question. There‚Äôs so much gray. Clearly, a post-op pt is a PT client. But, someone who‚Äôs having shld/back/knee stiffness, etc could fall into both the PT category and the wellness category. One thing I was well advised about is pricing. I suggest charging the same rate for PT as for Wellness‚Ä¶BECAUSE your long term wellness clients will likely need PT at some point and it‚Äôs too confusing (for both the patients and the business) to charge different rates for the same patient. I‚Äôm interested to see other comments here.

Cash based OT with mostly manual therapy skills/ortho/sports etc. 

How I approach wellness: 
Anything that needs more than AROM, MMT or orthopedic assessments for the evaluation I would consider skilled, for me. 
If I can do a rapid assessments and determine the cause of the problem through the three things mentioned above then I don‚Äôt consider it skilled, as a LMT could also do those things. 

How I approach skilled: 
usually this is a lot easier. People will come directly from the Dr or surgeon with a plan already in place. A diagnosis, recommendations, etc. Typically the more in depth standardized evals that will take an extended amount of time to perform and interpret are my signs that it is surely skilled. 

How I avoid the grey:
I just have everyone get a Drs referral. This helps the grey area and they can also deduct from their taxes as a business expense. So it‚Äôs a win win.

post_text: Anyone in this amazing group have success marketing directly to total joint replacement patients?  Any good tips/ tricks with this group? My mobile med B practice is nearly entirely geriatric deconditiong/ falls (which I love) but I'd love to get more into providing rehab post TKA and THA. Currently nearly all the Orthos in my area go to corporate owned dime-a-dozen type clinics and I'd love to break into that population more. Thanks!

comments.text:
Are any of them participating in the Medicare bundling?  I am mobile and I contract with an agency who works with an orthopedic surgeon who does the minimally invasive total knee replacement. It's same-day surgery patients are sent home, we see them post-op day one, teach dressing changes, monitor the incision and do the PT, all billed under outpatient benefits. 
Most patients get about 12 visits some don't need them all some need more. Way cheaper this way than using home health.

And the physician usually does a call on day one post-op and on day three. 

The company I contract for estimates that using us costs about $1200. If they start with home health it's so much more costly.  For difficult patients we do a pre-op visit so we can teach them everything they need with regards to equipment assessing the shower all of that.
Prove to the orthos why your personal attention is better, and I think they'll be swayed

post_text:
Need clinical advice:
I am treating a patient that has developed spasticity due to CAR T treatment. He‚Äôs cured from cancer however it gave him neurotoxicity. He was sent to me with symptoms of Parkinsonism. 
Due to severe spasticity his knees are locked at 40-50 degrees flexion. Wife states that at night he‚Äôs able to get better range. 
Does any know how I can work with something like this? Any recommendations on BL knee extension brace for extended stretch. Would that help?

comments.text: I‚Äôm working with a gentleman who has primitive reflexes after a brain injury. You may find your patient‚Äôs knees extend when he extends his neck. That is probably what happens when he lays down. If so, then go back to the basics of integration. It is working for me.

I‚Äôm writing in solidarity, as this has been heavy on my PT mind lately. I just lost a close family member last week (previously healthy and super active) to neurotoxicity and related side effects of this treatment. His team said some symptoms were Parkinsonian-like. Terrible, unfortunate loss. While I was hoping he would pull through, my PT brain kept fast-forwarding to the rehab stage and knew he‚Äôd need some super creative and perceptive neuro PTs on his side.  So sad for my family. I sure hope more research and discussion emerges on this topic.

full_thread_text:
POST: Need clinical advice:
I am treating a patient that has developed spasticity due to CAR T treatment. He‚Äôs cured from cancer however it gave him neurotoxicity. He was sent to me with symptoms of Parkinsonism. 
Due to severe spasticity his knees are locked at 40-50 degrees flexion. Wife states that at night he‚Äôs able to get better range. 
Does any know how I can work with something like this? Any recommendations on BL knee extension brace for extended stretch. Would that help?

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm working with a gentleman who has primitive reflexes after a brain injury. You may find your patient‚Äôs knees extend when he extends his neck. That is probably what happens when he lays down. If so, then go back to the basics of integration. It is working for me.

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôm writing in solidarity, as this has been heavy on my PT mind lately. I just lost a close family member last week (previously healthy and super active) to neurotoxicity and related side effects of this treatment. His team said some symptoms were Parkinsonian-like. Terrible, unfortunate loss. While I was hoping he would pull through, my PT brain kept fast-forwarding to the rehab stage and knew he‚Äôd need some super creative and perceptive neuro PTs on his side.  So sad for my family. I sure hope more research and discussion emerges on this topic.

post_text:
Hello everyone, 
I would love to get some idea ideas on how to structure commission for an employee  who does dry needling. 
The employee is paid $65 an hour. Dry needling charge is $45 for up to 3 body parts. It takes about 5-10 mins to do DN and usually is done within the hour of the patient treatment. All material cost is covered by the clinic. How much is a fair amount to give the employee as commission per dry needling encounter. 
Any suggestions/ other ideas are welcome 
Thank you!

comments.text: Dry needling certification is expensive and an asset to the clinic. I think it depends on how many patients are being needled by this employee as supplies are not cheap either. I would run some numbers and see how many patients would be needed to cover the cost of the supplies and maybe offer incentives to the employee based on the patients needled. If that‚Äôs too much to track then maybe split the charge.
$65 an hour sounds inclusive to me :)

post_text: Hey Vestibular PTs! How often do you perform on Epley on a pt with posterior canal BPPV? I‚Äôm asking for myself- had my first episode with it and am treating myself. Not something I generally treat, so any advice is appreciated. The first time did correct the nystagmus and I repeated it twice that day. But I am still lightheaded and slightly dizzy the next day. Thank you!!!

comments.text: Go check out my TikTok page on this topic @thedizzypt_amy.  I have a playlist on BPPV.  It's made for patients but will tell you a lot and answer a bunch of questions

I‚Äôve had success with 3-4 repetitions of the Epley at a time in one or two treatment sessions, a few days to a week apart. Try to avoid laying flat or looking up/down or bending over for 24 hrs after the treatment.

COMMENT 1: Go check out my TikTok page on this topic @thedizzypt_amy.  I have a playlist on BPPV.  It's made for patients but will tell you a lot and answer a bunch of questions

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôve had success with 3-4 repetitions of the Epley at a time in one or two treatment sessions, a few days to a week apart. Try to avoid laying flat or looking up/down or bending over for 24 hrs after the treatment.

post_text: Hi. Has anyone done a service exchange and seen a client for free? I'm an OT who is also pelvic floor therapist and I'm 31 weeks pregnant. I met a doula who would like me to see her for pelvic floor therapy in exchange for her doula services for me. Do you just modify or add in your paperwork to state something like - this contract guarantees 1 OT pelvic floor evaluation and 9 treatment sessions in exchange for complete douls services per ____'s contract." Or better language than that but still the same concept. Is there anything else I need to do in particular for this type of relationship and contract? Thanks for any help.

comments.text:
I am always wary of trades. Even if it seems even. Both your services have a monetary value, why not pay her and she pays you? 
And I his is 100% playing devils advocate what if she can‚Äôt attend your birth for some reason and you have already provided pelvic health services? Does she pay you back? What if you have a precipitous birth and she is only there for 20 minutes? Is it fair in exchange for 10 hours of OT or if she is with you for 36 hours because you have a long labor do you owe her money? I would make all these clear in the contract if you decide to go ahead. Ps I‚Äôm a pelvic health OT too :)

I always break down the cost, and apparently I‚Äôm the odd man out- but I LOVE trades ü§£. Been doing it for years! For doula services, I‚Äôd just divide her payment by your hourly rate and see how many sessions that gets, and put that in the contract. Barter systems are freaking fantastic IMO üôå

So if the doula costs $1200 and you charge $200/eval and $150/session, she‚Äôd get 1 eval and 6.67 sessions, which I‚Äôd round down and give her the extra $100 back to make it an even trade.

post_text: How do you best help your patients with HEP compliance? Besides talking to them about the importance/how they won‚Äôt get better just seeing me 1x per week/helping them come up with a time in their day. I know it varies patient to patient. What has worked best for you?

comments.text: Ask them how much time they are willing to commit to the hep during the eval. Then give them a clear understanding of how they‚Äôll progress based on that. And yes definitely incorporate into daily activities. Also discuss their why during the eval to improve compliance

What is their barrier to not doing? Sometimes we overcomplicate things for patients and they feel overwhelmed. Maybe identify 2-3 things most important to them and mimic that in the exercises. If they don‚Äôt feel they‚Äôre valuable to meet their goals, it doesn‚Äôt matter what we say or how great the exercises are. My favorite saying is the best exercise program is one that patients are willing and able to doü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü§£ 
There are some apps/websites that track compliance also

post_text:
Hello everyone! 
Apologies if this question has been asked here earlier. 

What kind of safety measures do you guys follow for yourself when you go to someone's house for home PT? I carry mace spray and have Google location on on my phone. But should I be doing anything else? 

I am a petite female and I am very strong for my size, but I'm just thinking and looking for ideas to keep my and my husband's mind at ease. 
Thanks.

comments.text:
1- know your quick exit just in case
2- sometimes I leave my airpod in my ear( and kind of cover with my hair
3- there were times where I would pretend to be taking or make a quick  call just to tell my husband where I am even if he is not on the other line ( of course I asked to be excuse for the call)
4- ask if they have pets- I went to a pt's house with a pet snake as fat as my thighs I almost had a heart attack
   Dogs- i am not scared of dogs but my PT friend doing HH got bitten by a dog who seemed mellow in the beginning
5- I try to keep the door open if I go a pt's private room esp if the pt is kind of off
6- I don't take food or drinks of they offer or if I take it- then toss it later- unless I am sure it is 100% safe
6- I bring a lab coat in case I am not wearing  scrubs- esp in not so good neighborhood- I put it on- 
 - my friend coached me this- he said people will respect you and believe you are out there helping sick people - :-)

I treat elderly folks with neurological conditions... generally I only treat folks I can outrun, but I keep my phone on me, and read the room.  If the vibe feels a little off, I try to make sure I'm closest to the door, and am mindful of who else is in the home.  I haven't felt the need for anything else. I had one inappropriate patient who said some things, I had to address, but nothing that bad.

post_text:
Does anyone here have any experience writing up a business proposal working with a club sport for high school students? And how did you determine your pricing?
Background: I have the opportunity to work with a volleyball club that I actually used to play for when I was in high school and have contacted the club director about providing PT/wellness services to the club‚Äôs players. Initially, I would do an injury screen to at least 1/4 of the players and give them 1-2 exercises if the screen came back positive for anything concerning. There is also the possibility of me providing 5-15 minutes of manual therapy to the players 1x/week during their regular practices. Both of these services would be paid for by the club and if any family/player wanted to hire me separately then that would be covered by the family/player.
Thank you!!

comments.text:
If you can... leave time out of it...   

For example don't say $30 for 15 min...

Base it on $300  to cover etc

Or.    $300 a day.  Or. $300 to serve 30 kids

make it about you being available, not just in doing

Make sense?!?

A point of reference: my daughter charges 50 per kid for 55 min OH hitting 2-4 kids , another defense trainer 1:1 45 min lesson $60-70. They all do conditioning training on the side 2X week at $25 session in groups of usually 5

post_text:
Billing questions: or maybe more accurately‚Ä¶ ETHICS questions‚Ä¶ 

For clinics that have patients ‚Äúwarm up‚Äù on an exercise bike, Are you considering that time skilled and billable? 

Do you bill for thera-ex or act when techs are instructing the exercises? If so, what level of supervision are you providing to the techs?

comments.text: Medicare and most insurances won‚Äôt pay for ‚Äúwarm-up‚Äù exercises or most equipment exercises if you aren‚Äôt documenting what ‚Äúskills as a licensed therapist‚Äù that you provided. I just saw a denial today from UHC where they stated ‚ÄúNuStep is not a skilled service‚Äù and they took back the money for the time spent on it.

The time you spent on set up and education of what you want them to do on the bike could be lumped into your billable treatment time. If they just head on back and get themselves on the bike, I would t count that time.

post_text: Hi everyone! I‚Äôm a pediatric PT and a certified massage therapist in CA. I‚Äôm interested in doing in-home massages and not any in-home PT (for now). Anyone have any idea how this might work if I want to keep these two lines of work separate legally speaking? Yet I do want to share that I am also a DPT to showcase my background. Thanks! üôèüèº

comments.text:
My question to you is why you want to separate it if you‚Äôre providing massage therapy?

Is it because you don‚Äôt want to do anything other than massage/MT? Or because you don‚Äôt want to do rehab? Or something else?

(I‚Äôm in California and a rehabilitation therapist ( unlicensed since there is no state license here. ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è) I personally provide movement and active manual therapy but my clinic offers straight massage as part of our services)

Your PT license covers manual therapy and as long as your clients understand your services with them will not be PT, where do you see the concern?

Market and sell massage therapy services. 

When you share about yourself you can speak about your education as a selling point. 

If you really want to ensure the separation, you can speak with an attorney to put language in your consent forms stating, this is not physical therapy.

post_text: Chronic pain focused PTs:  have you done your own workshops focused on chronic pain?  If so, who hosted them or who best to contact aside from pain management doctors?

comments.text:
Yes, I‚Äôve been teaching pain relief classes for years, both to lay people to relieve their own pain and to clinicians to learn my therapy approach to use in their clinics with their patients.

There‚Äôs lots of ways you can start teaching, and filling your classes.

The first step is to figure out who your ‚Äúdream clients‚Äù are and what‚Äôs causing their pain. 

For example, do you specialize in sports injuries, MVAs, fibromyalgia, migraine, etc.‚Ä¶

Once you know who you want in the class you can formulate the structure of it. ( 1-hour, 3-days, etc)

The clarity will also help you know who to connect with to help you fill it with participants or who might be interested in hosting it for you, such as other healthcare providers, athletic stores, professional organizations. 

If you feel good teaching to impart your wisdom and insight, it‚Äôs a lot of fun and very rewarding!
üíéÔøº

Ôøº
Have you ever heard of Adriian Ludou? He‚Äôs fantastic.

post_text:
My grandma had these XR taken after a FOOSH injury. Doc wants to go to PT to strengthen and strengthen the shoulder üôÑ. I see a humeral head dislocation inferiorly and AC jt separation. Anything else? Thoughts?

Update: 10/10 pain with shoulder flexion or abduction. Minimal to no pain when in sling.

comments.text:
I am sorry to hear about your grandma. I agree with Ethan other factors to consider. Her health mostly. 

But you can do stages of recovery. Such as sling for 4-6 weeks and isometric exercises etc and after send her back to Ortho for another imaging. I hope there is no fracture though.

Just my thoughts‚Ä¶ 

Conservative treatment may be the right option. If it‚Äôs not dislocated but instead lax due to soft tissue injury which seems very possible since those appear to be taken in standing, then there‚Äôs a strong likelihood for cuff tear. What‚Äôs the shoulders position in supine? Is your grandma able to be mobilized to assess laxity? If the deformity on xray is related to laxity then what other options does she have? At 80 cuff repair does not typically have great outcomes. Reverse TSA may fit but that‚Äôs a long rehab and likelihood she would be able to remain independent throughout the majority of it are really slim. If PT can manage pain and provide some stability to the shoulder so that it‚Äôs functional for her it‚Äôs potentially a win win.

post_text: This company near me offers Pelvic Floor Therapy. They are Naturopathic Doctors, all fine, but I noticed this on their website - are they able to bill this under PT??? That doesn't seem right.

comments.text: They can see the patient for pelvic therapyas a cash patient.  but it would be fraud to bill under Physical therapy and use the patients insurance benefits under PT if they are not a licensed PT

I do not know the answer to your question. I‚Äôm learning this too. But I do know that we as a physical therapy profession do not ‚Äúown‚Äù CPT codes, they are universally used in the medical field and selected by a provider and should only be utilized within a scope of practice. So therapeutic exercise can be used for different professions than just physical therapist. So physicians can bill 97110 and they would put their modifier instead of ours(GP). Also, the Herman and Wallace Institute allows a wide array of providers to take their courses, including Naturopathic Doctors. Many other pelvic floor courses can be taken by others. I know a personal trainer that calls her self a pelvic floor therapy specialist and states she has multiple pelvic floor certifications. So if it is the scope of treatment for Natropathic Doctors to perform and they have the skill set then I suspect they could bill. I see many different professions calling themselves pelvic floor specialists from holistic doctors to nurse midwives to personal trainers. Also, they are typically skillful with the wording calling it pelvic floor therapy instead of pelvic floor physical therapy.

post_text: Question, if you‚Äôre doing a straight cash based, al acart type side hustle - do you still do a direct access consent form? I‚Äôm in VA for context. I have no intentions on working with insurance. My side hustle is cash and performance enhancement/proactive in focus.

comments.text:
The short answer is if anyone is coming to you without a referral, regardless of the payment source, you must have a Direct Access Consent signed. 
The specifics of that form depend on your state practice act.

Cash vs insurance are billing models.  No matter which billing model you choose, direct access has to do with the service you‚Äôre offering being licensed vs non-licensed. If you are treating a diagnosis or providing a treatment and that classifies as a PT licensed service in your state, you have to follow direct access laws of your state. Example in Texas - you‚Äôd need to follow DA laws to administer hands on treatments and dry needling, but not consulting/coaching. Example 2 - you‚Äôd need to follow DA laws to treat knee pain (there is an ICD-10 code for knee pain so it‚Äôs a diagnosis), but not to help someone improve performance during squatting. Hope this helps.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: The short answer is if anyone is coming to you without a referral, regardless of the payment source, you must have a Direct Access Consent signed. 
The specifics of that form depend on your state practice act.

COMMENT 2: Cash vs insurance are billing models.  No matter which billing model you choose, direct access has to do with the service you‚Äôre offering being licensed vs non-licensed. If you are treating a diagnosis or providing a treatment and that classifies as a PT licensed service in your state, you have to follow direct access laws of your state. Example in Texas - you‚Äôd need to follow DA laws to administer hands on treatments and dry needling, but not consulting/coaching. Example 2 - you‚Äôd need to follow DA laws to treat knee pain (there is an ICD-10 code for knee pain so it‚Äôs a diagnosis), but not to help someone improve performance during squatting. Hope this helps.

post_text:
I'm in need of design-minded allies!
A good friend of mine offered to do my logo. I'm a Pelvic Floor PT running a cash -only practice out of my house. My name is Bottoms Up Pelvic Floor PT, and I thought that showed a bit of humor and relevance without being flippant. 
However - this logo is EXACTLY what I had in mind, but I'm finding that the actual two-dimensional image feels cartoonish, and doesn't really reflect the intimacy and seriousness of pelvic floor therapy. Especially pain and sexual dysfunction, which are my passion areas.
Is there a way to make a logo like this more... Appropriate? Do I need to abandon it altogether? If I abandon it altogether, any brilliant ideas about a motif that would be respectful of people's maladies and also relevant to the name of my business?

Thanks a million for your ideas!

comments.text: Just my 2 cents worth as a fellow pelvic PT: I'd go back to the drawing board, it is cute but might not communicate the message you intend. If I were having pelvic pain or sexual dysfunction, my first thought seeing the logo might be "um...am I gonna have to stick my butt up in the air"??? or "is this place a bar??" If you love your biz name and your current clients love it, great. But sometimes a fun name turns up not-so-fun stuff when doing a Google search for the same term...

I don't have any brilliant ideas, if one comes to me I will share it.

These do not speak to me at all I'm sorry to say. I agree that it lacks professionalism. üòï

post_text: Just sharing with like minds. This is my grandmas knee X-ray (permission to post). She has her TKA scheduled Tuesday this week. What the HECK!! Calcified quad tendon? Her joint surfaces actually look pretty good, right? I don‚Äôt read X-ray a lot but dang. How did this happen lol. And/or what the heck is this going on here.

comments.text: i'm sure that a strength deficit from a dysfunctional quad tendon can make her buckle easily  and fall. How old is she, is she walking with a device. You can most certainly delay the surgery while you get a 2nd and 3rd opinion; A quad tendon repair will be no fun but more appropriate than a TKR.

There are clear osteophytes and a decrease in joint space. That looks like a clear case of knee OA to me. Surgeons always tell patients that they're the ones to say when it's time for surgery. So if she's in pain and it's limiting her day to day function, do the TKA.

post_text: We‚Äôre a neuro PT/OT clinic. We‚Äôre going to do lunch and learn at a local ENT (for our vestibular therapist) and neurologist offices this month. Any suggestions of what to bring and how to structure it?

comments.text:
I used to work for a group of ENT's-- I was the director of their vestibular PT clinic.  What they want to hear is:

-Your vestibular PT knows what he/she is doing (certified in vestibular) and gets good results. 

-You get patients in quickly, especially the "emergency vertigo" cases.  Maybe even same day if they need you to.

-You have programs for treating their chronic vestibular diagnosed patients-- meniere's, vestibular migraine, etc.

-They'll also probably want to know what type of equipment you test and treat with (I.e. frenzel lenses, CATSIB platforms, etc).  You'll also want to show them anything special about your gym or space which makes it particularly "vestibular" in nature.

-And last but not necessarily specific to ENT's-- what insurances you take and how much it will cost their patients.
We always use a local Tex mex/Mexican restaurant & have them deliver to the office & set it up. They set up the taco bar & supply all the plates, napkins & cutlery. It‚Äôs an easy clean up!

full_thread_text:
POST: We‚Äôre a neuro PT/OT clinic. We‚Äôre going to do lunch and learn at a local ENT (for our vestibular therapist) and neurologist offices this month. Any suggestions of what to bring and how to structure it?

COMMENT 1: I used to work for a group of ENT's-- I was the director of their vestibular PT clinic.  What they want to hear is:

-Your vestibular PT knows what he/she is doing (certified in vestibular) and gets good results. 

-You get patients in quickly, especially the "emergency vertigo" cases.  Maybe even same day if they need you to.

-You have programs for treating their chronic vestibular diagnosed patients-- meniere's, vestibular migraine, etc.

-They'll also probably want to know what type of equipment you test and treat with (I.e. frenzel lenses, CATSIB platforms, etc).  You'll also want to show them anything special about your gym or space which makes it particularly "vestibular" in nature.

-And last but not necessarily specific to ENT's-- what insurances you take and how much it will cost their patients.

COMMENT 2: We always use a local Tex mex/Mexican restaurant & have them deliver to the office & set it up. They set up the taco bar & supply all the plates, napkins & cutlery. It‚Äôs an easy clean up!

post_text: Anyone out there with experience with a tibiofibular cyst?  This is a 16 yo

comments.text:
Multiple structures are often injured with a lateral meniscus injury and when repaired the meniscus is repaired but the other elements of the arcuate complex are rarely addressed.  This fixates abnormal
Mobility of the meniscus but neglects the other structures that MRI doesn‚Äôt pick up.  

In my office I‚Äôd check multiple angles of varus laxity (involved vs. uninvolved), tib fib motion as well as ankle mobility (tib fib mobility is exaggerated with ankle lateral instability) and appreciate under US the other stabilizing elements of the lateral complex bilaterally.

If you have a shockwave system it can help scar the capsules and components of the lax ligaments. Electrical dry needle placement on affected ligaments can help decrease laxity, but you‚Äôd have to place it on both ends of the affected tissue with the anode/cathode, and the needle placement needs to be precise.

Mri and X-ray negative when not swollen..6‚Äô6‚Äù. 180 lb..basketball player
No known trauma
History of lateral meniscus surgery one year ago..this was a symptom before surgery‚Ä¶no change after surgery 
HSS ortho has no diagnosis‚Ä¶just sent the picture to him

full_thread_text:

Mobility of the meniscus but neglects the other structures that MRI doesn‚Äôt pick up.  

In my office I‚Äôd check multiple angles of varus laxity (involved vs. uninvolved), tib fib motion as well as ankle mobility (tib fib mobility is exaggerated with ankle lateral instability) and appreciate under US the other stabilizing elements of the lateral complex bilaterally.

If you have a shockwave system it can help scar the capsules and components of the lax ligaments. Electrical dry needle placement on affected ligaments can help decrease laxity, but you‚Äôd have to place it on both ends of the affected tissue with the anode/cathode, and the needle placement needs to be precise.

COMMENT 2: Mri and X-ray negative when not swollen..6‚Äô6‚Äù. 180 lb..basketball player

HSS ortho has no diagnosis‚Ä¶just sent the picture to him

The massage therapist would perform  manual therapy (soft tissue) and then the PT would come in and do a little more quick manual (joint mobs,etc) and then proceed to do the rest of the appt like NM re-ed. post_text: Planning to launch concierge PT ( cash based ).. I am leaning towards  NEURO  PT as the focus  .. But being new practice  (I don‚Äôt want initially to loose patients by serving only  a subgroup , so  Shd I also include in my website or brochures that other ortho conditions/ wellness / pain mgmt will be treated as well ‚Ä¶.. or Shd I stick to one main focus area ‚Ä¶.. ALL SUGGESTIONS/ ideas are most welcome ‚Ä¶ thank you

comments.text: Myself (PT) and an OT colleague opened a neuro focused brick and mortar clinic about a year and a half ago and there is soooo much need for neuro specific care out there, people just don‚Äôt necessarily realize that not all PTs have the same expertise in treating neuro conditions. We have marketed only as neuro specialists and while it took some time and some work to get our name out there as the place to go for neuro PT and OT, it was definitely the right way to go. We have received referrals for other diagnoses and typically don‚Äôt turn people away if they don‚Äôt have a neuro specific diagnosis, but we don‚Äôt specifically market to other populations.

Keep it narrow.

It feels scary, but it's SO MUCH EASIER for folks to recommend you to their peers when they know EXACTLY what you do and the problems you solve.

(Easier doesn't mean it's the only way. And, you very well might see an initial dip in... Everything. Be prepared, be patient, and keep stepping forward.)

post_text:
Seeking advice for my aunt‚Ä¶
I must be a dinosaur‚Ä¶It seems to me that a TKR should receive more frequent PT than only 2x/week in post-op home PT.
My formative days after PT school were spent in intensive rehab (which doesn‚Äôt seem to exist anymore). We saw TKR and THR BID 7 days from post op day 1 until they were D/c‚Äôd home from rehab.

I know the current trend is to send patients home on post op day 1 with HH PT‚Ä¶.I fail to see how this is effective for rehab or achieving the minimal ROM‚Ä¶..
Am I missing something?  
Should my aunt (with Medicare) be receiving more than 2 45 minute sessions of PT per 7 day week or is this the new norm?  (I am horrified if so).
(Oh, and because it is a holiday week, she ‚Äúmight be seen‚Äù)

If this is the new norm, I am concerned that she‚Äôll never get the ROM she needs to function.
So the next question is‚Ä¶how soon can we get her to OP PT and would that have better frequency of treatment? Will she have better outcomes if she transitions to OP PT after 1 week at home (vs 4 weeks of 2x/week).

Can you hear my frustration?  I cannot believe that this level of care has the same outcomes as my patients in the 1990‚Äôs.

I would love to hear thoughts and suggestions for how I can guide this care. Do we push it with the surgeon to require more PT?  
Thank you!

comments.text: Let‚Äôs find a mobile therapist in your area! She could do that in lieu of HH.  That way she would get better care (more than likely) and be getting out-patient care sooner - but in the home!

Honestly the biggest obstacle to overcome is fear, and for most people pain = breaking something which feeds their fear. I literally don‚Äôt even lay hands on a TKR for ROM as I teach the patients what they need to be doing, and the only problems I‚Äôve had are ones I inherited from other therapists. I‚Äôd beüíØcomfortable doing a fresh TKR completely virtually. Same with other post op patients as well.
