Make the comparison about the patient, not the practitioners..

What are the patients‚Äô common pain points with chiros?

-The endless cycle of adjustment when that‚Äôs all they do: ‚ÄúI feel great after I got adjusted but a couple days later the pain always returns and I‚Äôm right where I started‚Äù 

-Signing up for some six month plan of 2-3x 
per week for $3,000

-Fear mongering by X-ray..‚ÄùThey took an X-ray of my back and told me how this little curve in my spine is causing me pain and if I don‚Äôt act now and sign up for six months my spine will continue to deteriorate.‚Äù 

If you can speak to these pain points and offer solutions (like how you can offer long term solutions that don‚Äôt involve signing your life away for six months; and how you help the patient build self care skills; and you‚Äôre not gonna take an X-ray just to tell people how crippled they are). I think that‚Äôs a better way to go. 

And you‚Äôre not even naming a profession by name; you‚Äôre just speaking to the frustrations that many people experience with the way certain practitioners work and saying you have an alternative and more enduring way that improves upon their pain points. 

Also, comparing ‚Äúphysical therapy‚Äù by name with chiro might fail too because lots of people have the experience of ‚ÄúI went to PT and they just gave me a sheet of core exercises that I could look up online and did nothing for my pain, but when I went to the chiropractor I felt amazing when I got off the table‚Äù 

Also, if we play the education comparison game, MD‚Äôs have us all beat, even though their expertise is mainly in MSK pathology and invasive procedures, but in MSK function we‚Äôre the subject matter experts

I dont believe this is true about you but it sounds too "inferiority complex-y" to me. I 100% agree and even believe a highly trained PT is better but I wouldn't compare. Just talk about what you can do, what you treat etc...

post_text:
For people who have small spaces but believe in heavy lifting, what do you feel is the most versatile piece of equipment for loading patients?

I currently have only a small room and have a pair of 15# and 35# dumbbells which has been limiting when I want to really load up for instance a deadlift. I don‚Äôt have room for a barbell or plates so I was thinking about getting a heavy kettlebell but then thought maybe I should just get heavier dumbbells or something else altogether. 

Would love any input! Thank you!

comments.text: Adjustable dumbbells/kettlebells (+lifting straps if grip is an issue) is one immediate change you can make. Another option is to think about what you'd like to accomplish? tissue tolerance? hypertrophy? you can use tissue tolerance exercises (e.g. drop sets, isodynamic sets, high reps) or strength endurance exercises like KB swings/snatches/squats/presses for time.

full_thread_text:

Another option is to think about what you'd like to accomplish? tissue tolerance? hypertrophy? you can use tissue tolerance exercises (e.g. drop sets, isodynamic sets, high reps) or strength endurance exercises like KB swings/snatches/squats/presses for time.

post_text: What do you think? Is this person avoiding  surgery? 35 yrs old, doesn't want Fusion and rods. I can help her but not sure it'll be enough to avoid surgery.

comments.text:
Surgery only with red flag symptoms‚Ä¶ bowel/bladder changes, progressive muscle wasting/weakness, etc. 

Surgery for pain is a coin flip at best, dangerous at worst.

He‚Äôs 35‚Ä¶ if otherwise healthy and uncomplicated non-surgical prognosis should be favorable. Natural history is favorable. Disc material resorption is very possible and even if not there are probably a million asymptomatic people walking around who would have the same findings in MRI.
One of my favorite professor quotes: I‚Äôd have to be peeing on my own drop foot before I got rods in my back.

full_thread_text:
POST: What do you think? Is this person avoiding  surgery? 35 yrs old, doesn't want Fusion and rods. I can help her but not sure it'll be enough to avoid surgery.

COMMENT 1: Surgery only with red flag symptoms‚Ä¶ bowel/bladder changes, progressive muscle wasting/weakness, etc. 

Surgery for pain is a coin flip at best, dangerous at worst.

He‚Äôs 35‚Ä¶ if otherwise healthy and uncomplicated non-surgical prognosis should be favorable. Natural history is favorable. Disc material resorption is very possible and even if not there are probably a million asymptomatic people walking around who would have the same findings in MRI.

COMMENT 2: One of my favorite professor quotes: I‚Äôd have to be peeing on my own drop foot before I got rods in my back.

POST: I received notification today from our local BCBS that they will start using Carelon‚Äôs Claims Anomaly Detection platform. Since I started my practice almost three years ago, BCBS has been super easy to deal with. Should I expect this will no longer be the case? I specialize in peds and adult neuro, both which tend to have longer care plans. Thanks!!

COMMENT 1: We have to use Carelon and it‚Äôs been a nightmare. I work in pelvic health and the POC is usually long, and a lot of patients have chronic pain conditions like endometriosis or sexual trauma histories. I get 4 visits at a time and have to do peer to peer reviews every single time I submit. Peds and neuro might not be as bad since there‚Äôs a lot more standard objective data you can gather. Insurance companies don‚Äôt care if you can‚Äôt have sex or use a tampon.

COMMENT 2: I haven‚Äôt received any notification like this but the last year has been miserable with BCBS.

Hey everyone!
I'm looking to make a graphic/poster for work that highlights the benefits of cash PT vs. insurance. I'm opening a new clinic inside a private training/classes gym and while we will accept both cash & insurance, I would like to start educating our clientele towards the cash routeüòÇ

Something that includes the number of visits, total cost of care, time invested, quality of care, etc. 

Any recent stats, references, articles or existing graphics are much appreciated!

comments.text:
I don‚Äôt have anything put together but currently working on a trifold pamphlets for some locations and highlighting tailoring specific client needs with in the scope of practice (pediatric OT here).  Number of visits and customizable treatment plans to fit the families needs and meet client specific goals.  No limits to the individualization of therapy plan.  No denials for services based on insurance limitations.  

I offer to adjust the treatment plan with more parent involvement in home programming up to multiple sessions per week if desired to maximize client progress.  Both are great ways to customize the therapy plan to meet client and family centered goals.  As stated above I work with kids so parent involvement always makes progress and carryover better.  

Hope this helps in some ways.  Don‚Äôt have graphics to share at this time.

post_text:
Any vestibular PTs on here with experience with horizontal canal cupulolithiasis?

I would love to pick your brain, treating my friend for free who has had recurrent BPPV over the years. Generally it's been in the posterior canal and we've treated it successfully  in one visit. 

This time around she appears to have it in the cupula of the horizontal canal and I'm having a tough time clearing it. Both sides symptomatic,  one side more intense 2 min duration, the other less intense  but 7-8 min duration. I have never seen this long of a duration of nystagmus and symptoms.  Ageotropic nystagmus on both sides.

Have done Gufoni with both  head up and head down on both sides, spaced days apart.

I'm almost starting to think it might be something else but wanted some input!

post_text: I have a client who's feeling really down about her TKR that she can't get full ROM out of. She's 4 months post op and current AROM is 6-103. Dr refuses to do a MUA bc he was worried he'd break her femur (she has extensive scar tissue from an accident thirty years ago). No other surgeon will touch it until she's a year post op. Right now we are continuing to stretch and stretch and stretch, but she's feeling frustrated and wanted to know how often this happens and what the outcomes are. I told her I'd poll the group bc I wasn't sure. Thank you for any input!!!

comments.text:
A few other considerations:
What was her ROM prior to TKR? In severe OA cases ROM can be quite compromised prior to Sx. Long term soft tissue contractures, muscle atrophy and fascial restrictions can take a long time to improve. 
Function is far more important than end ROM. 
Inflammation of local soft tissue and scarring can decrease over time. Patience is key. 
Pilates reformer exercises can work magic on TKRs.

My 2 cents:
1. How about focusing on function rather than pain. 
2. Her AROM is really good at 4 months, could also be that pain is inhibiting you from stretching further. Maybe she is over stretching and over doing her exercises. It is ok to decrease intensity and frequency to calm her pain down 
3. Icing is known to decrease C fiber activity. You can try stretch - ice massage- stretch- ice massage ‚Ä¶my experience with TKR, their knee tend to get very hot with movement 
4. Educate and re assure that she is progressing well - if patient sees that you are worried, she gets worried as well which will contribute to her pain experience 
5. Celebrate small wins

In my 7 years of practice, I have seen several TKR  cases from many years ago who were not able to achieve full ROM but they are not limited to what they can do

post_text:
Dry needling experts....

What is the research/your clinical experience on dry needling and knee pain in runners? Assuming that all the other bases are being covered as far as mobility, strengthening, running technique etc, is there value to doing dry needling in this population?

I would love to hear  more as I have no dry needling experience, ty!

I'm editing this for clarification. I'm NOT interested in doing this on a patient...I AM the patient in this case.  I am training for the New York City marathon and I've been having some knee issues lately.  So I wanted to learn more about the effectiveness of it for myself and I would go to someone who does it if it is worth my time.

comments.text:
It depends on where the pain is.  I‚Äôve done guided needling for a while and you can pretty much cure symptoms and pathology if done correctly.  Working on producing the research to support this.  To answer the question, patellar issues, quadriceps tendon issues, capsular issues around the patellofemoral joint - all very amenable to dry needling. Can stiffen up partially torn ligaments as well (superficial ones).

Try it,  you should find some benefits.

I have found it very helpful, especially some areas that are hard to get to manually. Recently had someone with strained post tib and ran half marathon with no pain after one session of dry needling with estim. Obviously results aren‚Äôt always that quick, but I would also argue it would be harder for me to address manually and his race was 5 days after treatment. 
But also depends on state as NY doesn‚Äôt allow PTs to dry needle.

post_text:
Where is your focus?

Wait. What?

Sunday, I was helping my daughter with her tennis. She simply wants to be able to hit with her friends who are better.

I finally realized that I was giving her the same feedback that I‚Äôve given to many many others who were looking to improve their game, which was ‚ÄúYES!‚Äù when the STROKE was desirable.

Not if the ball went in, or it was an amazing shot.

I told her that she probably wondered why I seemed excited on shots that, in her head, weren‚Äôt good shots.

I mean, some balls even went over the SIDE fence.

I said here‚Äôs why:

If you want to improve faster, you‚Äôre going to do so by understanding what you are doing right rather than worrying about what the outcome looks like.

In other words, get the process down, strengthen your foundations, and you will get a lot more right, hit a lot more good shots.

So, where is YOUR focus?

Is it ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get people to say Yes‚Äù - outcome focused

Or‚Ä¶

Is it learning an effective process that helps people to understand with clarity how you can help them- principle focused.

Something to think about ‚Ä¶

comments.text: Absolutely LOVE this!!!‚Äô
Great one David

post_text:
What have you guys told patients when you are leaving a clinic to treat independently? 

I‚Äôve kept it pretty vague, such as when my last day will be, who the therapist taking over is, etc, but I have quite a few patients who want to know where I‚Äôm going to keep treating with me. 
I know there‚Äôs basically the ‚Äúno poaching‚Äù ethics and what not, but one of my patients said today that it‚Äôs his right to want to continue with a therapist that he trusts and sees results with. 
Having a hard time determining if I‚Äôm in the wrong bringing patients with me who have vocalized wanting to continue treatment with me, even if I wasn‚Äôt at this specific clinic anymore rather than switching to the new PT.

comments.text:
Hi all!
Thank you for all the feedback and suggestions. I had a conversation with our clinic owners and was told they have no issue with me sharing my professional email or social media with patients to ask questions/keep in touch, and if that leads to them choosing to treat with me then so be it. They did ask that I do not share specifics of my plan, such as treating mobile, etc, unless asked after my departure from the clinic, which I more than understand.
So for now, I will just be passing that info along, if asked, and keep advocating for the new PT coming in because he‚Äôs a great new grad with a lot of love for the professionüôÇ

Maybe I'm the odd one out here, but when I left my job to open my own practice I "poached" pretty much every one of my active patients. 
Context. I am a pelvic floor PT. I was honest with everyone that I was leaving on X date, and was leaving to start my own private practice. I didnt ask any of them if they wanted to come with me, but every single patient asked if they could continue their care with me at my new location. I gave them the option of staying at the current clinic and working with the other pelvic PT. Nope, no takers. If they asked directly, I just gave them my new contact info, and had them contact me later to schedule.  ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è  Patients have the right to see what provider they want to see. As long as you are not going out of your way to market to old clients, or push it, they can come to you.

Does that vary by state ? Also is stretching under a tech or professional degree? When is it flexibility ex and when is it ‚ÄúManual Therapy ‚Äú?

COMMENT 2: Our techs (high schoolers/college kids) did ultrasound on patients and one clinic I worked at had those same kids stretching hips when PTs were triple booked. And on the same note, who is stretching people at these stretch clinics that are opening everywhere? Certainly not therapists.

post_text:
Has anyone ever asked to be at a PT/trainer at a school for athletes to check in on and possibly attend games? They have been left without an athletic trainer and their president is possbily interested in brining in an independent.  
SO...what would I even ask for?  A salary? A hourly pay?  Assuming I can go in and evaluate, treat like a PT?  I'm also a CSCS (strength & conditioning certification).  Can I do this even if I'm not an ATC?  I'm licensed in MN

comments.text:
I'm a PT/ATC. I would check your practice act. Make sure you're comfortable with acute injury management: spineboarding, splinting,  concussion, return to play decisions. Expect lots of blood and using a lot of supplies you're not familiar with if never trained. You'll be dealing with split chins, nose bleeds, vomiting, heat illness, dehydration, etc. 

It's doable but must be ready for it all.

I‚Äôm a PT/ATC - I would check your state practice act for scope of practice. I would also make VERY sure that your insurance covers you. Hourly is going to be your best ask as far as pay. Games can last a really long time and coaches/schools will take advantage if you‚Äôre salary. I will also say - I‚Äôve worked as a PT and I‚Äôve worked as an ATC. I cannot stress enough how if you are on sidelines as medical personnel you need to be ready for anything and everything as far as emergency management and be prepared for the stress of coaches and parents screaming at you from the sidelines as you make decisions. The only part of my education that was the same was eval/rehab. Sideline coverage/emergency management was a big part of my AT education and not at all part of my PT education. Sideline coverage is a whoooooole other thing (and I hate it and don‚Äôt do it anymore lol).

post_text:
I'm treating a husband and wife at their home.  I have a mobile/cash PT practice.  The husband has psoriatic arthritis, is a fall risk, has some mental illness and PTSD.  At evaluation, he was upfront about his alcohol and cocaine use.  He says he's allergic to narcotics and breaks out in a rash so he is managing his pain the only way he knows how.  

He has no showed 3 times now because he was too ill to do his session.  Today, his wife went to get him for his appointment and she came back saying he wanted to cancel today and he was using cocaine in his bedroom.  

Husband and wife live pretty separate lives and may become legally separated soon.  I want to help, but I left today feeling a little uneasy.  I'm worried that he's unstable and unpredictable and could be impaired during our sessions and I want to make sure I'm safe.

I've never come across this situation before, and I'm not one to give up on people.  Any advice for me?

comments.text: I would say PT probably is not his most urgent need. I would advise another service to treat his mental health and addiction first and return to PT if he is able to adhere to some treatment. For me it does not sound like you will achieve much with PT alone at this stage. Perhaps he needs a multidisciplinary organization.
I‚Äôd say cut your losses. It sounds like he values his time significantly more than yours. I can almost guarantee nothing will change and most likely get worse.

post_text:
Hi! I am a PFPT (have my DPT) & a certified doula and work with prenatal and postpartum populations. There is a huge demand for prenatal massage in my area. Is there a way for me to get ‚Äúcertified‚Äù in prenatal massage? I know technically massage is a skill we know as PTs, but I‚Äôm also looking for a way around needing referrals.

Editing to add: I‚Äôm in Texas bc I know that probably makes a difference.

comments.text:
Since you have your DPT, in Texas you can technically evaluate and treat for 10 days without an order.  

I‚Äôm sure you have an established assessment/ evaluation process, and treatment would be the pre-natal massage as indicated.  The pre-natal population sees their providers regularly, so when the pre-natal client leaves your care after the first massage, they could take a referral/order for continued pre-natal massage for the referral‚Äôs signature.  Then you‚Äôre covered for longer than 10 days with the signed order.  

The PT Rules state a reassessment is required every 60 days at a minimum. 

Thanks for providing your much-needed services in the Permian Basin!
You would need to attend an accredited lmt school and have an lmt license in conjunction with your PT. They may let you out of some of the classes.

post_text:
Good morning everyone. Does someone have experience working with patients after peroneal tendons repair? I have patient who had repair done many years ago and his main complaint is not being able to do SL calf raise on the surgical side along with instability. I researched some articles about peroneal tendon repair which were mostly case reports written by MDs and they reported "good" or "great" outcomes with no other details. Is there any possibility that those patients will never be able to do full calf raise on the surgical side?

My patient is 40-year-old personal trainer who is very active and exercise on daily basis.

comments.text: Thank you for all the comments! So after my eval here are some important takeaways: 1. Pt did "rehab" by himself (due to various reasons). Personally I think this is where the problem stems from. He did some exercises but I believe he did not have proper and progressive progression, as well as other set of eyes to see if he is developing compensations. 2. I learned from surgical report that his ankle was fused due to instability (ATFL and CFL) as well as his peroneus brevis was used to reconstruct the longus. 3. Based on my objective eval I deduct not only severe weakness in triceps surae complex but also in flexor digitorum longus (MMT of toes 2-5th are maybe 4-/5 at best). 4. During SL and DL heel raise pt demo'es ankle supination which looks like dominance coming form tibialis anterior and posterior . Thus my plan is to do progressive strengthening of triceps surae etc. I showed pt mobo board  but I recommended doing custom modification to have digits 2-5th do the work, not 1st ray, on top of other strengthening exercises. I plan to sprinkle in exer such as toe yoga so pt is able to learn dissociation between his 5 digits üôÇ TLDR: all we need to do is progressive overloading!
I‚Äôve seen a few of them for post-op rehab. They all did well and were able to do SL calf raises by d/c with pretty symmetrical excursion to non-operative side.

full_thread_text:
POST: Good morning everyone. Does someone have experience working with patients after peroneal tendons repair? Is there any possibility that those patients will never be able to do full calf raise on the surgical side?

My patient is 40-year-old personal trainer who is very active and exercise on daily basis.

COMMENT 1: Thank you for all the comments! So after my eval here are some important takeaways: 1. Pt did "rehab" by himself (due to various reasons). Personally I think this is where the problem stems from. He did some exercises but I believe he did not have proper and progressive progression, as well as other set of eyes to see if he is developing compensations. 2. I learned from surgical report that his ankle was fused due to instability (ATFL and CFL) as well as his peroneus brevis was used to reconstruct the longus. 3. Based on my objective eval I deduct not only severe weakness in triceps surae complex but also in flexor digitorum longus (MMT of toes 2-5th are maybe 4-/5 at best). 4. During SL and DL heel raise pt demo'es ankle supination which looks like dominance coming form tibialis anterior and posterior . Thus my plan is to do progressive strengthening of triceps surae etc. I showed pt mobo board  but I recommended doing custom modification to have digits 2-5th do the work, not 1st ray, on top of other strengthening exercises. I plan to sprinkle in exer such as toe yoga so pt is able to learn dissociation between his 5 digits üôÇ TLDR: all we need to do is progressive overloading!

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôve seen a few of them for post-op rehab. They all did well and were able to do SL calf raises by d/c with pretty symmetrical excursion to non-operative side.

Are you passionate about helping individuals improve their pelvic health and overall well-being? We‚Äôre seeking a skilled and compassionate Pelvic Floor Therapist to join our team.

Responsibilities:

‚Ä¢Evaluate and treat patients with pelvic floor dysfunction, including but not limited to urinary incontinence, pelvic pain, and pregnancy/postpartum issues.
‚Ä¢Develop individualized treatment plans based on thorough assessments and patient goals.
‚Ä¢Utilize a variety of evidence-based techniques, including manual therapy, therapeutic exercises, therapeutic activities, and neuromuscular re-education.
‚Ä¢Educate patients on pelvic floor anatomy, proper body mechanics, and self-care strategies.
‚Ä¢Collaborate with interdisciplinary healthcare professionals to provide comprehensive care.

Requirements:

‚Ä¢Master‚Äôs or Doctorate degree in Physical Therapy or Master's degree in Occupational Therapy from an accredited program.
‚Ä¢Valid state license as a Physical Therapist or Occupational Therapist.
‚Ä¢Specialization or level 1 certification in Pelvic Floor Therapy (preferred; although mentorship is available).
‚Ä¢Strong interpersonal and communication skills.
‚Ä¢Ability to provide compassionate and empathetic care in a sensitive setting.
‚Ä¢Commitment to continuing education and staying up-to-date with current research.

If you‚Äôre ready to make a positive impact on the lives of patients and contribute to their overall wellness, we‚Äôd love to hear from you!

To apply, please send your resume and a cover letter highlighting any relevant experience to info@tayloredhealwell.com

post_text: What certifications and extra training has resulted in the biggest ROI for all you cash based peeps?

comments.text:
Short answer:
Dry Needling & any Pelvic Floor knowledge.

Long answer:
Learning about whatever I‚Äôm most passionate about ‚Äî in formal and informal ways.  Me being excited & having solutions for my clients is more important than any single certification. 

Mentorships ‚Äî informal from colleagues & formal online programs. 

Getting treatment from a wide variety of other providers.  Even a bad massage  has lessons to be learned. 

Manual therapy ‚Äî if people like the quality of your touch, you‚Äôre gold.

I only dry needle ~50% of the people who specifically book asking for DN. Often they are relieved it‚Äôs optional.  

But yes, I do think DN is a good skill for cash PT ‚Äî unless you can adequately compensate with other strengths.   

The more I learn about Pelvic Floor the more effective my sessions are.   Much more powerful than DN.   I only do external PF and it‚Äôs still been a game changer.  (Well PF Dry needling is great too!)
manual therapy cert.....the skills, not the extra letters.......and its not even close

full_thread_text:
POST: What certifications and extra training has resulted in the biggest ROI for all you cash based peeps?

COMMENT 1: Short answer:
Dry Needling & any Pelvic Floor knowledge.

Long answer:
Learning about whatever I‚Äôm most passionate about ‚Äî in formal and informal ways.  Me being excited & having solutions for my clients is more important than any single certification. 

Mentorships ‚Äî informal from colleagues & formal online programs. 

Getting treatment from a wide variety of other providers.  Even a bad massage  has lessons to be learned. 

Manual therapy ‚Äî if people like the quality of your touch, you‚Äôre gold.

I only dry needle ~50% of the people who specifically book asking for DN. Often they are relieved it‚Äôs optional.  

But yes, I do think DN is a good skill for cash PT ‚Äî unless you can adequately compensate with other strengths.   

The more I learn about Pelvic Floor the more effective my sessions are.   Much more powerful than DN.   I only do external PF and it‚Äôs still been a game changer.  (Well PF Dry needling is great too!)

COMMENT 2: manual therapy cert.....the skills, not the extra letters.......and its not even close

I'm looking into switching from Medbridge to Physitrack for HEP.

I've had a lot of complaints from patients about the Medbridge App.  When using the "coaching" option that runs them through the exercises, the rest breaks and hold times are off and it has been confusing to some.  They have complained that a couple of simple exercises have taken them 45 or more minutes to complete because the "coaching" option is slow (it should take around half that time).

Does anyone have any patient feedback when using Physitrack?

comments.text: You should try AC health! It‚Äôs a video HEP format where you can record or have pre-recorded exercises for your client. It‚Äôs extremely easy, my patients tell me they like it more than a paper version and I have their HEP done before they even leave my office!

I had to use physitrack at my old job, no complaints. A few patients downloaded the app but not a lot. I still honestly preferred HEP2gos program, although there‚Äôs no app the exercises were much easier to find and more what I needed. Again, there‚Äôs no app to that one but it‚Äôs free!

post_text:
Hi all! My first post here. I‚Äôm a full time hand therapy OT, and have been a clinician for 2 years. I love it, but I feel like there‚Äôs more I want to do. I tried a different setting (inpatient rehab) but that did not light me up at all and I won‚Äôt be proceeding with that. It‚Äôs an odd feeling, like I‚Äôm in an egg trying to break through. 

Is this a feeling I need to investigate more? I‚Äôm hopeful some of you can provide some wisdom here. 

My brain immediately thinks of being a ‚Äúfunctional movement specialist‚Äù. Focusing on the aging population living and moving through their environment from an OT perspective, but with a strength based approach incorporated too. 

I‚Äôm worried with the strength based approach is it coming off too much like a personal trainer? 

I‚Äôd love to hear some feedback. If you have made it this far, thanks for reading!

comments.text: Hey! What‚Äôs wrong with a strength based approach? As health care providers we have a duty to do things that are going to push our patients health forward, and nothing comes close to exercise and strength training. And the aging population definitely needs it! The benefit of doing something strength forward as an allied health provider is our understanding of the MSK system. I would say you‚Äôre much better qualified to do this than a personal trainer, especially for that age group. What in particular are you worried about?

Just a thought if you want to explore many OT settings before settling down you could try travel OT. 3 month contracts that pay VERY well and try different settings. I did Acute, IPR, Occupational medicine and outpatient. I would have loved to have tried something in PEDs the pandemic hit though and I wanted to be home.

post_text: What is ur rate for just dry needling? Where are u purchasing needles from?

comments.text: Dry needling is included in my plan of care and I never do it without exercise or neuro re-ed to follow up. It‚Äôs a disservice to patients to needle them without following that up with retraining the muscle. They will feel good for a bit then have to come back for more needling since the underlying issue isn‚Äôt being addressed. My visits are getting ready to go up to $180 this summer. I pretty much use only Serins from Lhasa since I can use them for try trigger point dry needling as well as with STIM or for fascial/scar needling. They are the most versatile needles I‚Äôve found for all the ways I utilize it in my practice
PT is not a drive-through or ala carte service. Dry needling should be part of an overall plan of care.

post_text: Question‚Ä¶dos anyone else see a trend in so many people being put under hospice, especially in facilities? I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs so that they can receive more care with ADLs and equipment, meds, etc and lighten the load of the staff. My issue is that I‚Äôm receiving therapy orders but treat them the same as I would any of my patients with setting goals and working toward return to PLOF or maximizing functional mobility and I just got a letter from CMS basically stating my utilization is higher than the national average and I should check for compliance. Am I wrong in trying to treat these patients the same as I would any? Especially if their diagnoses and potential don‚Äôt necessarily mean a death sentence per say.

comments.text: My understanding is that unless you are treating something unrelated to the hospice dx, then you can not bill Med B.  If they require PT, then the hospice company should be providing services under Med A.  Goals under hospice are different as the person is not expected to return to PLOF.
I was under the impression that once a patient is in hospice you can‚Äôt treat them under Medicare part B, I‚Äôm not sure if that‚Äôs a law or policy but it‚Äôs what my company does that I work for

And another question for those of you who do group wellness exercise classes for older adults...I feel really silly to ask, but how do you come up with your programming - keeping it fresh and such?  I mean, I know exercises, but the thought of coming up with content that is general enough for a group for ongoing classes feels stressful.  I mean, I could totally present a class someone else planned, but to come up with it on my own...

Or any resources for already developed group exercise class content?

post_text: Anyone have experience with TENEX for lateral epicondylitis? Good success? Healing time? I have a patient that is asking me about it. Thank you!

comments.text: I did prolotherapy and it worked great. Better than surgery and down time. TENEX is supposed to work well.

If the diagnosis is accurate and the person has observable tendinosis at the extensor group on the lateral epicondyle it can be helpful.  Rehab is longer if there is hyperemia on US.  If the person has a tear within the capsule of the RC joint then this will only partially alter their pain.

If you‚Äôve done dry needling to the region that is planned for the procedure several times (especially with periosteal pecking) and they haven‚Äôt noticed any changes then this procedure has a lower likelihood of changing things since your needles couldn‚Äôt affect the pain generator.

full_thread_text:
POST: Anyone have experience with TENEX for lateral epicondylitis? Good success? Healing time? I have a patient that is asking me about it. Thank you!

COMMENT 1: I did prolotherapy and it worked great. Better than surgery and down time. TENEX is supposed to work well.

COMMENT 2: If the diagnosis is accurate and the person has observable tendinosis at the extensor group on the lateral epicondyle it can be helpful.  Rehab is longer if there is hyperemia on US.  If the person has a tear within the capsule of the RC joint then this will only partially alter their pain.

If you‚Äôve done dry needling to the region that is planned for the procedure several times (especially with periosteal pecking) and they haven‚Äôt noticed any changes then this procedure has a lower likelihood of changing things since your needles couldn‚Äôt affect the pain generator.

Can you legally treat a patient that is a resident in another state that is a student in the state you practice in??

I haven't ran into this situation yet!

I practice in Wisconsin and they are a student living in Wisconsin and employed in Wisconsin but again an Illinois resident.

comments.text: Are you treating them in the state you practice/are licensed in? Then yes you can treat them. I assume they are of legal age or have a parent/guardian consent. It's about where YOU practice, not where the patient lives.

Yes. I have a patient now who resides in PA but has been traveling the country doing comedy. I‚Äôm treating her in IL in person. 

Also when I was a student in IA doing PT, I was an Illinois resident.

First of MANY nervous posts, I am sure...A shared space recently popped up as a very affordable option to light a fire for starting to have my own practice. (I am excited and nervous, and my husband is very skeptical).
It is happening very fast. My original plan was to cut my hours at work starting in July to start the process but now the timeline is greatly accelerated to May 1. 
1. My specialties are Balance/Vestibular and Aquatic- are there Aquatic therapists here that have been successful renting pool time from condos or hotels?
2. As far as a name goes does "The Nerdy PT" sound off-putting? Would it be a deterrent for the Geriatric population?

comments.text:
Idk about pools, but make some calls to places local to you. 
Not liking the name Nerdy PT. Why Nerdy? Is there math involved? Nerds to me are computer oriented, not physical.
Renting pool time in condos or hotels will be iffy bc of liability issues. Your better off renting from a privately owned pool.

post_text:
Question for the cash based Pelvic PTs. 

Looking into the cash based model for pelvic health.  I live in a wealthy populated area with lots of potential for cash business. 

My initial research on current cashed based pelvic businesses is indicating that a lot of the clientele using cashed based pelvic PT are young athletic prenatal and postnatal clients, Cross fitters, marathon runners, triathletes, etc.  

Do cash based pelvic PT‚Äôs see many older/menopausal women with pelvic floor dysfunction manifesting as dyspareunia/constipation/fecal incontinence/urinary incontinence?  
I have built an excellent reputation with local primary care and specialist MDs working with this client base over several years.  I know when I go cash based those MD referrals may drop off.   I want to be realistic about whether or not the older clients I excel with will go for cash based pelvic services.  

Any input is appreciated! 

Posting anonymously so as not to alert my current employer. (Still caged)

comments.text: I think a lot will depend on if there are good pelvic PTs in the area who do take insurance.
I am a pelvic PT and while mostly cash based, I am participating with Medicare and offer to check out of network benefits for others. It only deters some older clients.

post_text:
Are we as PT's able to utilize something like ethyl chloride or any other numbing spray prior to Dry Needling? If so, what do you use?
I have had a few patients ask me if I had any sort of numbing spray.

comments.text: Not sure if we are allowed to use it or not or not, but a big part of the mechanism behind dry needling is the gate control theory of pain. Without the painful stimulus from the needle, you lose that potential neuropathic mechanism of healing. Still get the increased blood flow from micro trauma and twitch response but I think that‚Äôs an important piece of the healing process.

I don't think a numbing spray would be of much help as the initial price of the skin is minimal in my experience.   It wouldn't help with the deep ache people experience or stronger twitches.   As some said earlier,  there are alternative treatment options.   I frequently use SCS for patients who are needle phobic or just don't want dry needling.   I personally don't find it quite as effective but try to accommodate people as much as much as possible

full_thread_text:

Without the painful stimulus from the needle, you lose that potential neuropathic mechanism of healing. Still get the increased blood flow from micro trauma and twitch response but I think that‚Äôs an important piece of the healing process.

It wouldn't help with the deep ache people experience or stronger twitches.   As some said earlier,  there are alternative treatment options.   I frequently use SCS for patients who are needle phobic or just don't want dry needling.   I personally don't find it quite as effective but try to accommodate people as much as much as possible

post_text:
Hello!
I have a medicare patient who i have been seeing for a left ankle fracture, she has now seen a different doctor and received a second script for a different right knee injury. As a provider can I treat her for both injuries on the same day and keep her for an hour and a half and get paid on both cases? The patient wants to know if she needs to see a different provider so she can receive treatment 2 days a week for her knee and 2 days a week for her ankle. The only problem is i am currently open 3 days a week, so i would need to see her one of the days for both appointments if she stayed with me. Would medicare reimburse me for both knee and ankle cases separately? They come from two different doctors and injuries.
Thank you!

comments.text: Anthony Maritato speaks about charging for the 2nd body part, but keep it all in one case. Tony, am I correct with this?

Do a re-evaluation, in the assessment explain why that the re-evaluation was done which is to update the plan of care to include the new condition which requires it's own POC/eval. The re-eval is going to update current s,o, and a, add new goals, update old goals, add a new plan. 

On treatment days, you're going to get reimbursed on what you did and how you treated. At that point it's no different than if they had walked in with both problems at the same time. You may need to extend treatment time, but you don't need to add a treatment day unless you want to.

post_text: Dreaming here and looking for advice from those who have done it or hired those who have changed from an inpatient/home care setting (x 5 years) with no outpatient experience aside from clinical in school about 6 years ago. My dream would be to work with the ‚Äúaverage person‚Äù and do a combination of personal training and injury prevention and physical therapy. I‚Äôm active myself (runner/swimmer/yogi). Thinking about dabbling in personal training to develop that higher level exercise prescription, but unsure of what would be my next best move. Thanks in advance - also hope this is ok to be posted! Please delete if not ok. TIA!

comments.text: I graduated in 2017. Worked inpatient rehab for a year and have been in home health for the rest. I just opened my business in December, a mobile outpatient PT business. I love working with post op patients, post hospital patients, Parkinson‚Äôs, and stroke patients. So generally lower level patients. But I‚Äôve had a few people who just want to be active again and have an exercise program started up for them. You GOT this!! There is something for everyone out there. I see people dealing with aches and pains who want to reduce pain and then go on a wellness program with someone who knows more about their diagnosis or condition. It‚Äôs doable, you CAN DO IT!! There‚Äôs so much to learn but this community is the bomb. There‚Äôs a niche for everyone. A lot of PT‚Äôs here in my town have a space in a gym or CrossFit gym type area and work with weekend warriors. They are amazing at what they do, a combo of PT and training. Think about what you love to do and that‚Äôll help you decide. What would you do for free if you never had to make another dollar in your life? ü§ó

I transitioned from 5 years of acute care and 3 years in geriatric to go back to more traditional outpatient and sports. 
First of you have to remember that as a PT you‚Äôve probably forgotten more about this stuff than most people will know in their entire lives, so you‚Äôre very qualified even if out of practice! Biggest thing was just brushing up on special testing, reviewing some courses on conditions that you might feel a little rusty on. 
Overall it‚Äôs mainly the flow of evals and treatments that takes a little time to get back into. But you‚Äôll be fine and your background in acute or inpatient is a huge huge huge bonus when working with folks who have been through it or when seeing more medically complex patients. It‚Äôs a strength not a liability!

post_text:
Quick question:
I‚Äôm PT. Do I need a special certification to perform a Functional Capacity Test? Pt is applying for disability. 
TIA

comments.text:
The words you choose to use here are important.

A functional capacity evaluation as a very specific test. I used to perform them and yes, I went through the training in with certified.

But my guess is nobody is asking for an FCE.

SS and disability doesn‚Äôt require an FCE. 

https://secure.ssa.gov/apps10/poms/images/SSA4/G-SSA-4734-U8-1.pdf

It really depends on who is paying for it and what they require. Can I evaluate ones functional capacity and report it to you? Yes. Am I certified in Isernhagen? Not anymore. Does that stop case managers from requesting that I evaluate a client's ability to safely climb a step stool and retrieve a 50# item from overhead as part of a progress note or reevaluation? No it does not. Do I offer 8 hour FCEs anymore? Nope.

post_text:
Has anyone discharged a patient who they felt uncomfortable treating? IVe been treating a 20yo young man with pelvic floor issues. I‚Äôve felt uncomfortable with him from session one. Nothing that he is doing per say. There is just something. My sessions are 1-1, in closed door, very personal of course, given the nature of the sessions‚Ä¶ and he is not inappropriate, I can‚Äôt tell what it is, but there is something that leaves me on edge every session the whole session. Our improvement has also not been great. There is still time for improvement, but usually by this point there are great shifts happening already. And in his case there has been zero changes.
I am continuing because I am the only pelvic floor therapist in my area who will see males, so I feel bad discharging without giving a referral to someone else‚Ä¶ but I don‚Äôt think I am the therapist who will facilitate the results he needs. Thoughts?

comments.text: Read the book The Gift of Fear - it‚Äôs by a former homicide detective. He points out that female humans are the only mammal that will discount their own internal warning system because they don‚Äôt want to make the other human ‚Äúfeel‚Äù bad. He makes a great example of a woman about to get on an elevator with a man - the woman‚Äôs intuition tells her there‚Äôs something off with the guy‚Ä¶. The woman overrides her intuition and gets on the elevator anyways because she doesn‚Äôt want the man to think shes‚Äô a‚Ä¶ snob, racist, a bit@h, whatever‚Ä¶ the author points out that you‚Äôll never see a gazelle get into a closed metal box with a lion - You don‚Äôt owe him more than a polite discharge on the next session. You‚Äôve obviously been experiencing these feelings for many sessions - time to honor them.
Your intuition is telling you everything you need to know.  Discharge him based on no progress made, and refer him back to his physician.

comments.text: My opinion is that exercise is wellness if it‚Äôs not addressing a specific established diagnosis, AND therex become exercise after you‚Äôve taught it. I think that for too long PT has been a crutch for people who need accountability.

As Abby Regan said, the minute the conversation becomes ‚ÄúI want you to‚Ä¶‚Äù vs ‚Äúyou need‚Ä¶‚Äù it‚Äôs wellness. How many times have patients begged you not to DC them from therapy even when it‚Äôs not medically necessary. ‚ÄúBut I just can‚Äôt do it with it you, you encourage me and I do it better with you.‚Äù 

What they are asking for is personal training paid for by insurance. That‚Äôs a come to Jesus conversation about what MC SHOULD have to pay for vs what the PATIENT should have to pay for

post_text:
Admins, please delete this if it's inappropriate. 
For those of you experienced in treating Parkinson's, do you often see exacerbation of disease post surgery...ie joint replacement?

comments.text:
Don‚Äôt quote me on this but what is it the average person takes 3 days of exercise to recover per each day in a hospital 
With PD it‚Äôs like 7-10 

I treat tons of PD patients like 70% of our practice and anecdotally - everything gets worse after surgery and typically double to triple what a non PD time frame is to get better  post surgery.  

Side note I have seen some amazing improvements with patients post DBS  immediately out of surgery. But then again that was specifically for their PD symptoms.

I experienced this a lot in inpatient rehab! We'd get total knees with Parkinsons there more for PD than knee. Def a flare up after or also felt/wondered if their medicine wasn't as effective right after surgery. Would usually phrase it as "your body requires extra time to process, including your healing." Completed less TherEx and a lot more Big movement work outs. 
The pain associated with improving range would also trigger more sx. As long as the range was functional we limited heavy interventions to improve to full(at least in acute phase). Same with new learning for compensatory strategies depending on where they were in their disease progress. Focused on what they felt was most important: usually going to the bathroom, but could care less about shoes kind of compromise in independence goals.

post_text: Finally came up with a name for my uncaged business. What are some pros/cons to adding "& Wellness" to ___ Physical Therapy? I hope to do cash practice but not 100% on that yet.

post_text:
Okay posting this to see how this could even be feasible. 
I love working with stroke clients and do extra CEUs and certsnpertaining to stroke even though when I see them in my current role can be few and far between (although they send tons my way when they have them). Just recently I‚Äôve had a couple strokes who were told in rehab they‚Äôd never walk again and I‚Äôve gotten them walking with assist in the first few sessions. It may not ever be their primary mode of mobility but the fact that they see they CAN at all is a huge motivator for them and family. And I always preface with ‚Äúthis may still not be your main mode of mobility and we have to figure out a way to be at peace with that‚Äù. 
That being sad I‚Äôve toyed around with an idea of how I could develop a post ‚Äútraditional‚Äù therapy route where I can further work on their skills and recovery, at the point where many start to drop out of the system because they‚Äôve ‚Äúplateaued‚Äù. 
I follow a coupke insta accounts of therapists who specialize in niche and iffer ‚Äúintensives‚Äù like a 2-4 day program that focuses on them for x hours a day obviously with built in rest, but trying to do a ton of reps in a short period of time to re stimulate neuro plasticity to add more skills, awareness, activation, etc. 
now how the heck could one even attempt to start this. I‚Äôm thinking because it‚Äôs so out of the box it would have to be private pay, not sure how I could ‚Äúbill that‚Äù but then it also filters out all the Medicare clients which is a huge part of the stroke victim community. 
Also licensing, I would think the easiest way is for them to travel to me but that‚Äôs not always feasible either. And not sure how that works if I‚Äôm licensed in one state (it is a compact state) and they live in another. Or whether travel for me would have to be inckuded for me to travel to you (which could put a strain on us as we have 3 girls under 5 and my husband works long hours in food and beverage hospitality). 
Like I said, I‚Äôm not even sure something like his would be feasible, but when I give clients that glimmer of hope it‚Äôs amazing. Not only that but their transfers get significantly better once they learn to trust that impaired leg even just a smidge which decreases caregiver burden. 

If you‚Äôve made it to the end, thank you! And thanks in advance for any advice!

comments.text: You need to chat with David Bayliff, Josh Payne, or Kevin DeGroot! I see your passion and your dream all over this post and that‚Äôs half the battle of getting started! Now you just need direction! I wish the best for you!

Offering adaptive fitness/wellness training is a niche that rehab clinicians can be well suited for.  I've spent 6 months training a person with an incomplete SCI.  He returned to his neuro out-pt PT and they are impressed with how strong he is!  Which has accelerated his progress with all mobility and gait.

post_text:
HELP! I'm in Ohio for reference. I am going thru the practice act, but it is so unclear to me. 

I am a certified manual therapist and that is a big part of the way I practice. I'm still a bit confused as to my place in this therapy / wellness world. I have a fully cash practice, no insurance. If I see somebody and do any sort of manual therapy corrections of the spine or pelvis or anything like that does it automatically make it physical therapy instead of wellness? If so, do I need to have a plan of care in place in their chart? For wellness, I just do it "as needed". People seem to really like the flexibility of coming when they want and are using me effectively. However, I want to be in compliance with our state practice act, and have my malpractice insurance cover me. Generally, many of my wellness patients are one-time monthly. Since that is the case, doing a progress note every 30 days does not make sense. I'm doing more "maintenance" work. However, during those sessions, I often use manual therapy ( manipulation, joint mobs, soft tissue work, dry needling, etc.) to get them aligned so that they're exercises are more effective. 
Can someone speak to these things? Can I do whatever they need if they are paying for a service, or am I operating outside our practice act? If all I need is a plan of care, I can add that easily. If I have to send to Dr, I think it's a bigger deal just because I don't see individual patients with a high frequency. I'm more of a maintenance program.

comments.text: If fully cash, why would you need notes at all or any sort of plan of care except as a reminder for you for the next session? No electronic record, no HIPPA. Assuming your malpractice is as a PT.

I prefer to think of wellness as ‚Äúcould a personal trainer legally do this?‚Äù So I would not dry needle or manipulate a patient that I‚Äôm seeing for wellness. A massage therapist, those places that stretch people, etc. - those don‚Äôt require an MD Rx, providing exercise plan doesn‚Äôt require an Rx. So I would look more into what your practice act specifically puts under the term personal trainer and also what it says specifically about dry needling and manipulation.

post_text:
Question- 

I have an individual who just wants cupping done. 

Am I able to JUST do a cupping treatment session and give her that superbill or does she NEED an evaluation prior to get reimbursed?

Or do I require the entire evaluation for the first visit and can do only cupping after that?

comments.text: That‚Äôs an ‚Äúa la carte‚Äù service. If cupping is the only thing they want, you can just charge cash for a wellness/recovery visit. PT is a full eval and YOU decide whether cupping is the most effective tool to use. I do PT and also provide DN and recovery massage as a la carte services‚Ä¶.although i will mention that some PTs prefer not to do this bc what ends up happening is that patients JUST come for those services and don‚Äôt actually make the huge improvements like they could. Right now, providing a la carte services align with my business goals but i can definitely see people prefer not to provide it. Make sure you‚Äôre charging for your time appropriately!! Massage therapists make at LEAST $1/minute and that‚Äôs excluding tip, mobile services, and additional modalities. My rates are $2.5-3/minute. I know you didn‚Äôt ask‚Ä¶.but I figured I‚Äôd just put it out there. Hope that helps!!  üòä

If you‚Äôre wanting to submit for reimbursement it needs to be a physical therapy visit, meaning you would need to follow your practice act, which I would assume means evaluation. I perform evaluations and treat the same day every time. 

If you‚Äôre not performing ‚Äúphysical therapy‚Äù and are doing ‚Äúwellness‚Äù then you would not use CPT codes and not submit any sort of super bill.

I know you didn‚Äôt ask‚Ä¶.but I figured I‚Äôd just put it out there. Hope that helps!!  üòä

post_text: I have a potential referral for a child with duchenne muscular dystrophy. My background is orthopedics and I don‚Äôt have experience with this diagnosis. However, the mom really wants someone to come to the home because it is too hard to get him PT. With full disclosure to the mom about my background I would be willing to work with this client because she doesn‚Äôt have any other options. Homecare wouldn‚Äôt provide long enough care to the client and she would do cash pay with me. I wanted to ask the group for general recommendations in working with this diagnosis and if you think I could take this on. I don‚Äôt know the patient‚Äôs condition yet and am trying to go into the phone conversation with the mom prepared. Thank you.

comments.text: If you have a PT or OT degree then you have the Background needed to treat this population. Use you critical thinking and all the tools in your tool box. The hard part is setting realistic measurable goals. Might have to do some research. Dig deep. You won‚Äôt regret it. I had a friend with Duchenne‚Äôs who live to be 55. He taught me a lot about being a human and the need to be able to verbalize exactly what you need to get the care you need/desire.

Prognosis is not good‚Ä¶very sad to see such kids‚Ä¶there is a lot of atrophy and hyper trophy of muscles( especially calf with classic gower‚Äôs sign where a patient ambulates on all 4‚Äôs) ‚Ä¶eventually diaphragm muscle is involved in the last stages‚Ä¶your best bet is to stretch all the muscles of the body‚Ä¶pnf techniques,keep the Rom / function as much as possible and a special focus on diaphragmatic , lat coastal expansion and other breathing exs‚Ä¶hope that helps..all the best..whatever you do will help the child..

He taught me a lot about being a human and the need to be able to verbalize exactly what you need to get the care you need/desire.

He had surgery in July on his knee (TKA) and I was under the impression I had to stop treatment since I had been working shoulders/neck and LEs as well. 

A local private PT company I‚Äôve partnered with told me that he can have multiple POC at the same time as long as it is different body parts. I sent same patient recently for some neuropathy treatment at another clinic (hospital based OP) but they wouldn‚Äôt see him and almost forced him to do all his PT with them. I did a Google search for information on this and didn‚Äôt find what I was looking for. Anyone have any experience with this or know who is right in this situation?

comments.text: Only one per day.  Medicare won‚Äôt pay for PT on two different POC on the same day.

They can have multiple open POC, you just don‚Äôt want them to overlap and double schedule on the same day 

Medicare Billing for (Mostly) Cash Based PT, OT, SLP Providers Group is a good resource for questions like this üòä

full_thread_text:

A local private PT company I‚Äôve partnered with told me that he can have multiple POC at the same time as long as it is different body parts. I sent same patient recently for some neuropathy treatment at another clinic (hospital based OP) but they wouldn‚Äôt see him and almost forced him to do all his PT with them. I did a Google search for information on this and didn‚Äôt find what I was looking for. Anyone have any experience with this or know who is right in this situation?

COMMENT 1: Only one per day.  Medicare won‚Äôt pay for PT on two different POC on the same day.

COMMENT 2: They can have multiple open POC, you just don‚Äôt want them to overlap and double schedule on the same day

The beauty of the "uncaged life" is being able to say: "I don't treat/specialize in that, but I would be happy to provide you with the contact information of someone who I think would be a great fit to help you" 

There was a time when I felt so pressured to take cases that I just  wasn't confident treating...even though a clinician better suited for the case was often in the same clinic üòñ

It honestly makes me so happy to have the resources to refer to clinicians that I KNOW are a better fit than I am :) 

Happy for this group that has opened my eyes to this  AND introduced me to great clinicians in my state and other states!

post_text:
Anyone doing concussion evaluations/assessments? I was curious if Physical Therapy is classified as a ‚Äúqualified healthcare provider‚Äù for the following CPT codes. 
ÔøºCan we bill for the evaluation under code 96132 or would that be our regular PT low/moderate/high complexity evaluation?

96132/96133 (neuropsychological evaluation by physician or other qualified healthcare provider first 60 min/additional hours)

96138/93139 (psychological/neuropsychological test administration performed by physician or other qualified healthcare professional first 30 minutes/additional 30 minutes) 

Any insight is appreciated, thank you!

comments.text: Cognitive screening measures (impact, moca, etc) are not billable or equivalent to standardized cognitive assessment performed and interpreted by Neuropsych or SLP. Screening measures can be given by nurses or athletic trainers. I can't imagine these CPT codes would fall under the scope of practice of a PT
Depends on what you are doing in your evaluation and treatment. Are you using anything like imPact?

full_thread_text:
POST: Anyone doing concussion evaluations/assessments? I was curious if Physical Therapy is classified as a ‚Äúqualified healthcare provider‚Äù for the following CPT codes. 
ÔøºCan we bill for the evaluation under code 96132 or would that be our regular PT low/moderate/high complexity evaluation?

96132/96133 (neuropsychological evaluation by physician or other qualified healthcare provider first 60 min/additional hours)

96138/93139 (psychological/neuropsychological test administration performed by physician or other qualified healthcare professional first 30 minutes/additional 30 minutes) 

Any insight is appreciated, thank you!

COMMENT 1: Cognitive screening measures (impact, moca, etc) are not billable or equivalent to standardized cognitive assessment performed and interpreted by Neuropsych or SLP. Screening measures can be given by nurses or athletic trainers. I can't imagine these CPT codes would fall under the scope of practice of a PT

COMMENT 2: Depends on what you are doing in your evaluation and treatment. Are you using anything like imPact?

post_text:
Hey all, I would love some advice, feedback on a current patient (one of my business's biggest cheerleaders) as I'm developing my ortho spine/pelvis knowledge and skills (I'm mainly neuro).  I am aware that MRIs are not always needed/necessary, etc, but I did attach the last half of an MRI for extra info.
Patient a 76 yo female, hx CVA w/ very mild right spasticity 1 year ago, has been practically pain free (orthopedically) for years.  107 lbs, eats as healthy as able.  She does have a noticeable dextroscoliosis of her lumbar spine.  Over the last month or 2 she has developed pain in right buttock, occasional n/t down lateral right leg with insidious onset.  She has had massages, chiro decompression, estim, manipulation (they sold her quick after her seeing her xrays), and will attempt dry needling tomorrow.  Everything feels better then comes back, but she's also taking max tylenol and now gabapentin daily.  She is mainly seeing me for balance, but we've tried manual therapy, exercises, etc and her pain does not seem to be improving.
I welcome any and all thoughts on other ways to assess, and help her reduce her pain.  Feel free to private message me
Thank you!

comments.text: As already written, had a pt whose pain didn‚Äôt resolve until the cyst was removed. My other thoughts are along with strengthening of hips, gluts and core she would likely benefit from manual LE distraction and self decompression. My experience with stenosis is distraction over time has a cumulative effect and then follow up with home decompression program. I like to use Sara(h) Meeks. She‚Äôs a PT that developed a program to decompressed the spine, mainly for those dealing with osteoporosis where certain movements should be greatly limited or avoided. Had very good success with it (like doing it for myself sometimes).
May be hard to get good strength testing because of stroke but how is that L5 myotome? There are times where symptoms match with MRI and give a better idea of the problem.

post_text:
I'm a mobile PT with a patient with very stubborn frozen shoulder.  Any good tips besides passive and active stretching?

Addendum: doing lots of mobs in all planes and dynamic functional reaching. Addressing scapula and TS and CS.  She received a cortisone shot last week.  Not able to do dry needling because I am in CA.

comments.text:
I agree with RK in that it is more of a chemical/hormone problem most likely. 

The manual and Therex is great but it really just serves as theatrics until the body figures it out. 

I find that once my patients understand the reality that it isn‚Äôt dangerous and they should stop or avoid doing things, they tend to embrace the ‚Äúit is what it is‚Äù attitude and do pretty well. 

I explain how exercise may acutely benefit the chemical environment, so it doesn‚Äôt matter what you do as long as you do something and do it frequently.
Have you tried TMR?

full_thread_text:

Addendum: doing lots of mobs in all planes and dynamic functional reaching. Addressing scapula and TS and CS.  She received a cortisone shot last week.  Not able to do dry needling because I am in CA.

COMMENT 1: I agree with RK in that it is more of a chemical/hormone problem most likely. 

The manual and Therex is great but it really just serves as theatrics until the body figures it out. 

I find that once my patients understand the reality that it isn‚Äôt dangerous and they should stop or avoid doing things, they tend to embrace the ‚Äúit is what it is‚Äù attitude and do pretty well. 

I explain how exercise may acutely benefit the chemical environment, so it doesn‚Äôt matter what you do as long as you do something and do it frequently.

COMMENT 2: Have you tried TMR?

post_text:
Dry needling question - 

I‚Äôm located in California and I know the law prohibits PTs from performing dry needling; however, I am also a certified ATC in which dry needling is allowed in CA. I‚Äôve heard ‚Äúit‚Äôs based on your highest level of education‚Äù but I also have colleagues that perform dry needling as ATC. Any insight would be helpful. Thanks!!!

comments.text: Sorry, I have no input, but that scenario is insane. Mind blown.

So ATCs are not regulated in  CA, no governing body to dictate what can and cannot be done within the state. As far as dry needling, my understanding was that in CA it can only be performed by acupuncturists and MDs. Weird loophole it seems. I would think reaching out to the PT board might be the safest legally, although they will likely tell you that you can‚Äôt perform it. If you do, absolutely take coursework/get certified before performing the intervention! Interested to hear what the outcome is.

The only possible exception may be to touch base with surgeon if it is post op to make sure you maintain a good working relationship (if he sends you tons of referrals but hates or doesn‚Äôt understand  needling, for instance)

post_text:
Hi group, long time follower, First time poster. I am contemplating starting up a mobile practice and maybe add a brick and mortar spot if the business justifies it. I currently work home heath 3 days a week and 2 Saturdays a month in acute but also have peds and outpatient experience. I am saddened on the push to DC people so soon from home health and now the census had been very low. I enjoy working with the older adult group especially those with PD and dementia as well as those who are generally weak. I'd like to keep it cash pay/private pay to avoid  insurance altogether. 

My questions are: The older adult population is heavy Medicare so can you even offer cash services for physical therapy or does it have to be marketed as wellness? 

What are good software programs to use for documenting as well as for accounting purposes? 

How do I go about marketing myself initially to the community? 

Thank you all for reading this far.üòä

Picture for a chuckle üòÜ

comments.text: Hi, geriatrics are my niche and I am only cash based.  I don't find it very difficult to brand what I am doing as wellness with this population bc most of my people really want a consistent exercise program that doesn't change alot,  and they also don't progress quickly,  if at all. Medicare would never pay me for what I do with them bc we aren't working toward specific, measurable goals, and I don't modify treatment plans very often. I have a few people who are more acute and have goals but they are usually seeing another therapist under Medicare during that acute period too,  so I am the uncovered service again.  I just use Google docs for barebones documentation bc no one is ever going to ask for it üòÜ
Too funny, home health is my main gig too. And I cringe when they say walk right in.... always feel like a burglar ü§£

post_text:
Looking for some billing advice.... 

I currently work at a hospital based outpatient clinic. I usually feel that their ethics are good, but I‚Äôve recently started dry needling and was educated to bill it as manual therapy. I don‚Äôt feel comfortable with this, but they haven‚Äôt been willing to set up a cash pay system for dry needling. Do I continue to dry needle and not bill for it? Or just tell them I will no longer be providing dry needling services?

comments.text: The answer is actually really simple. The Insurnace companies tell you. I can‚Äôt answer for you as it depends on where you are but all Insurnace companies very specifically tell you what to bill and if covered In their medical guidelines. Just a quick google search‚Ä¶. Hope that helps

I'm not sure why you feel it isn't manual therapy? 
Imo, with PT services, our time should be reimbursed the maximum amount, because it shouldn't matter what we choose to do in our tx session; it should all be up to us. Why would we not get the best reimbursement for our time?

post_text:
Hi guys. 

I'm wondering who gives the BEST Dry Needling Courses/Certs especially for the Pelvic region (my main reason for going)?

Apparently, it looks like I need 40hrs of academic and 40hrs of hands on instruction in order to practice DN in my state. So it looks like  getting the certification is the way to go.

Any thoughts on this would be helpful?

Thanks in advance.

comments.text: I‚Äôm certified through Myopain Seminars‚Ä¶. I thought they did a fantastic job! To get certified it was 3 3day weekend courses.  To learn the pelvic floor would be additional on top of that.

I did mine through Evidence in Motion, used to be Kinetacore. They have Functional Dry Needling level 1(2-3 days)you then have to do 100 sessions before you can do level 2(2-3 days). They have a pelvic floor dry needling course but it requires level 1 and 200+ sessions I believe. I‚Äôm a huge fan, I think it‚Äôs a safer approach than others I‚Äôve seen but I kind of boils down to this: if you want a faster more condensed course, go with another company. If you don‚Äôt mind taking the time to learn it all, 100% do this one.

full_thread_text:

I‚Äôm a huge fan, I think it‚Äôs a safer approach than others I‚Äôve seen but I kind of boils down to this: if you want a faster more condensed course, go with another company. If you don‚Äôt mind taking the time to learn it all, 100% do this one.

post_text: Don‚Äôt know if this is allowed‚Ä¶Can anyone recommend a good tennis shoe for my nephew who has always toe walked and now at 7 yrs old is experiencing heel pain. My sister has taken him to an ortho, but she didn‚Äôt feel he answered all her questions so she made an appt with a pediatric ortho in a neighboring bigger city.

comments.text:
Plantar Fasciatis? Have you recommend PT? Release of gastric/soleus/anterior tibialis?  Hamstrings? 

I am a big fan of barefoot shoes, but they are not for everyone. 

Xero brand is lovely. Soft, flexible soles, wide toe box, they look like normal shoes. They have sizes for men/women/children, a great exchange policy and you can measure at home..

I have completely eliminated my own bunion pain with stretches, exercise, and barefoot shoes. 

Disclaimer: I am a medical massage therapist, reflexologist, and CST (not a PT)

For the most immediate relief- she could add cushion heel cups to his current tennis shoes. Sounds to me like on top of toe walking history, he may have some Severe‚Äôs going on too. Definitely get a PT referral

I am a big fan of barefoot shoes, but they are not for everyone. 

Xero brand is lovely. Soft, flexible soles, wide toe box, they look like normal shoes. They have sizes for men/women/children, a great exchange policy and you can measure at home..

I have 2 questions for the group: 

1) Does anyone know if free PT treatment can count toward state requirements for minimum hours worked (for WA state PT license renewal)? Would include skilled eval, treatment, documentation, etc.

2) Can a cash pay PT treat Medicare patients for free as a community service (since you cannot charge for treatment)?

comments.text: No. Cannot treat for free. Volunteer at a free clinic. Medicare covers services you are to try to collect the coinsurance 20%. You are not required to take them to a debt collector

I got a message through my Google listing from a guy claiming to be a tennis instructor. He said he is getting back surgery soon and wants a physical therapist to work with 8 of his athletes in different injuries and wellness stuff. Seemed a little sketchy at first but I was excited about the opportunity. 
He is offering to pay for all 8 athletes in advance. Not sure how it would be a scam as he said he would give me the credit card info to run. I would require him to give it over the phone instead of text. I‚Äôm not sure how it‚Äôs a scam yet but still sketchy. There are a couple red flags such as him listing a bunch of cities that are spelled wrong and he said he is from a city in Utah that doesn‚Äôt exist. His English isn‚Äôt great and all of the contacts have email addresses that appear to be a combination of their last and first name. 

Anyways, I‚Äôll keep you posted as I learn more info. 
Anyone have any experience with a situation like this?

post_text:
Hello! I was wondering what the top notch weight lifting certification programs are? Preferably one non biased to thick thighs üòÇ

In undergrad I would beat most classmates in the 1 and 2 mile races we had, placing third in female/male races. I beat everyone in the class in the blindfolded balance board exercises. We had university BB players, lacrosse players and football players in that class. And I lasted longer running while having VO2max tested. That was great because it smashed misconceptions about big girls and the re-defined what ‚Äúfit‚Äù or ‚Äúathletic‚Äù means. I have a couple weight lifting courses I‚Äôm looking at but they seem very generic. Any and all advice appreciated üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

comments.text: I would go for the CFMA Cert from ICE. It will cover the Olympic lifts plus a lot more and be much more applicable across the board for many types of fitness athletes. This is coming from someone with an Olympic Weightlifting background and the USAW level 1. Unless you only want to work with Weightlifters, but they will likely look for someone who has weightlifting experience before coming to you to be honest.

Another vote for the ICE CMFA certification, I'm so glad I did that over USAW to get started. It changed my lifts immediately in the gym and also gave awesome groundwork to start treating active people that love/need to lift. Also great crew of people to get involved with in general!

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello! I was wondering what the top notch weight lifting certification programs are? Preferably one non biased to thick thighs üòÇ

In undergrad I would beat most classmates in the 1 and 2 mile races we had, placing third in female/male races. I beat everyone in the class in the blindfolded balance board exercises. We had university BB players, lacrosse players and football players in that class. And I lasted longer running while having VO2max tested. That was great because it smashed misconceptions about big girls and the re-defined what ‚Äúfit‚Äù or ‚Äúathletic‚Äù means. I have a couple weight lifting courses I‚Äôm looking at but they seem very generic. Any and all advice appreciated üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

COMMENT 1: I would go for the CFMA Cert from ICE. It will cover the Olympic lifts plus a lot more and be much more applicable across the board for many types of fitness athletes. This is coming from someone with an Olympic Weightlifting background and the USAW level 1. Unless you only want to work with Weightlifters, but they will likely look for someone who has weightlifting experience before coming to you to be honest.

COMMENT 2: Another vote for the ICE CMFA certification, I'm so glad I did that over USAW to get started. It changed my lifts immediately in the gym and also gave awesome groundwork to start treating active people that love/need to lift. Also great crew of people to get involved with in general!

post_text: Just need a little refresh. Medicare patients need a progress note 30 days or 30 days re-assessment?

comments.text:
As of 2008 a POC can be certified up to 90 days.  the 30 day requirement ended Dec 31 2007. Source CMS chapt 15 page 171.

C.  Review of Plan and Recertification Reference:  42CFR424.24(c), 1861(r), 42CFR 410.61(e). The timing of recertification changed on January 1, 2008.  Certifications signed on or after January 1, 2008, follow the rules in this section.  Certifications signed on or prior to December 31, 2007, follow the rule in effect at that time, which required recertification every 30 calendar days. Payment and coverage conditions require that the plan must be reviewed, as often as necessary but at least whenever it is certified or recertified to complete the certification requirements.  It is not required that the same physician/NPP who participated initially in recommending or planning the patient‚Äôs care certify and/or recertify the plans. Recertifications that document the need for continued or modified therapy should be signed whenever the need for a significant modification of the plan becomes evident, or at least every 90 days after initiation of treatment under that plan, unless they are delayed.

Progress Notes every 10th visit..  looking for source reference.  pg 184
Progress Reports (including Discharge Notes, if applicable) when records are requested after the reports are due.  (See definitions in section 220 and descriptions in 220.3 D); 

pg 191: 
D.  Progress Report The progress report provides justification for the medical necessity of treatment. Contractors shall determine the necessity of services based on the delivery of services as directed in the plan and as documented in the treatment notes and progress report.  For Medicare payment purposes, information required in progress reports shall be written by a clinician that is, either the physician/NPP who provides or supervises the services, or by the therapist who provides the services and supervises an assistant.  It is not required that the referring or supervising physician/NPP sign the progress reports written by a PT, OT or SLP. Timing.  The minimum progress report period shall be at least once every 10 treatment days.  The day beginning the first reporting period is the first day of the episode of treatment regardless of whether the service provided on that day is an evaluation, reevaluation or treatment.  Regardless of the date on which the report is actually written (and dated), the end of the progress report period is either a date chosen by the clinician or the 10th treatment day, whichever is shorter.  The next treatment day begins the next reporting period.  The progress report period requirements are complete when both the elements of the progress report and the clinician‚Äôs active participation in treatment have been documented. For example, for a patient evaluated on Monday, October 1 and being treated five times a week, on weekdays:  On October 5, (before it is required), the clinician may choose to write a progress report for the last week‚Äôs treatment (from October 1 to October 5).  October 5 ends the reporting period and the next treatment on Monday, October 8 begins the next reporting period.  If the clinician does not choose to write a report for the next
