So make sure you ask your audience what they‚Äôd like to see. 

üíó

post_text: Hi all! I‚Äôm doing a presentation this week (half hour) to young gymnasts (ages around 10-12). I have some content ready (stretches, when to use ice versus heat etc)- but is there any other glaring content you think is good specific for gymnasts? Any suggestions helpful! I was a gymnast when I was young so I do know that side of it, but I‚Äôm looking for other specific ideas I should talk about or good resources!

comments.text: I would talk about how food fuels performance.

Fueling for training, performance & recovery!  Maybe briefly touching on the fact that it‚Äôs normal & healthy to get a regular period, since they are close to the age it will/should start. Also, i like to use a guideline of age = absolute max training hours/week (so a 10 year old shouldn‚Äôt be training more than 10 hours/week), and that should include all aspects of training not just the actual gymnastics part. I can‚Äôt remember where I got that, I think from CSM when I was a new clinician.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi all! I‚Äôm doing a presentation this week (half hour) to young gymnasts (ages around 10-12). I have some content ready (stretches, when to use ice versus heat etc)- but is there any other glaring content you think is good specific for gymnasts? Any suggestions helpful! I was a gymnast when I was young so I do know that side of it, but I‚Äôm looking for other specific ideas I should talk about or good resources!

COMMENT 1: I would talk about how food fuels performance.

COMMENT 2: Fueling for training, performance & recovery!  Maybe briefly touching on the fact that it‚Äôs normal & healthy to get a regular period, since they are close to the age it will/should start. Also, i like to use a guideline of age = absolute max training hours/week (so a 10 year old shouldn‚Äôt be training more than 10 hours/week), and that should include all aspects of training not just the actual gymnastics part. I can‚Äôt remember where I got that, I think from CSM when I was a new clinician.

ATTN: BOOTCAMPERS!! ü•æ

You should have just received an email about bootcamp starting up tonight with our first training at 8pm EST!

If you did not receive an email, it is most likely that you did not click the button that allows us to send you emails üò¨. So I wanted to make sure that you got the info here as well! 

Here is what the email said:

Welcome to Uncaged Bootcamp! We are so excited that you are here. It is going to be an amazing 4 weeks as we grow our businesses together.

First, we have our first training tonight! We will be covering legalities and logistics, and much, much more. Reminder: The training is TONIGHT, July 5th at 8pm EST.

Third, For those of you that just recently signed up over the past 60 days: You should have received an email from Kajabi immediately after you signed up to create your new account. Please do so as this will give you access to your kajabi account where all of the training replays will be stored. 

I'm looking forward to an amazing night tonight! And I am looking forward to being your coach for the next 4 weeks üôÇ

Please email: Josh@uncagedclinician.com if you have any questions! And to get the zoom link for tonight. (Please email only if you are a part of Bootcamp üòÉ)

post_text:
AW RITE! AW RITE! AW RITE!

It's FRIDAY!! ü•≥

Time to KICK IT UP A NOTCH! üï∫

First, let's all give a loud RRRROAR to welcome our new members! ü¶Åüëã

Super stoked for Keri Markut.  She got her FIRST CLIENT this week for her new, budding practice!! LET'S GOOOO!!! üí™

Lindsay Kennedy and Matt Sullivan celebrated their 1 and 2 year UNCAGED anniversaries, respectively! CONGRATS!! ü•≥üéâ

Erica Parazo has Kicked It Up by getting dual Board Certified for Clinical Specialist in Geriatric PT AAAANNNND in Neurologic PT!! That's bamtastic!!! üëä

Cindy Carron Weinberger and her practice Kicked It Up this week with EIGHT new referrals and all of her contractors are full!!  BOOOM!!! üéâ

There's Kicking It Up a Notch, and then there's KICKING IT UP A NOTCH.  Joe Orbaczewski and his wife, Kelsey, did that latter with the birth of their beautiful little girl, Aubrey!!! üéâü•≥

Kash Mahdi and wife, Jen also KICKED IT UP A NOTCH!!  They brought little Mikaela Quinn into the world!! ü•≥üéâ

One way to establish Famousity is to get on tv.  That is exactly what Kitiboni Physio did this week!  She appeared on a local morning tv show!!  BOOM SHAKALAKA!! üï∫

Another way to kick things up is to finish first place in age group in a triathlon.  That is exactly what Jennifer Reed and her sisters did at Ballast Point: Little Italy (San Diego)!! WAY TO GO!!ü•á

Kristine Everett and *former* boyfriend, Justin, took things next level.  They got engaged!!! CONGRATS!!! üéâüéâüéâ

Being a guest lecturer is another way to increase one's Famousity.  Doing so will be DeAndre Caldwell!  He announced that he will be a guest lecturer at the National Pain Conference this August in Dallas, TX!!  SOLID, my man!!!üí™üëä

Super excited for Haley Naegeli and her hubby.  They WILL be KICKING IT UP A NOTCH this December.  They just announced that baby Naegeli will be arriving at the end of the year!! üéâ

Jacoby Cotton. BRO. SOLID.  In case you missed it, this dude took the prize in his body building competition.  I'm never taking off my sweat shirt again.... üí™üí™üí™ü•á

KICKING IT UP was Ashley Linton Dundon and her hubby!  They welcomed their precious little Wylder Luke into the world!! üéâüéâ

I got mad, MAD respect for my boy, Joe Daigneau.  There is running, and then there is ruuuuuning.  The dude just placed in an ULTRA marathon.  All I know is that ULTRA means he ran a long long way.  SOLID, BRO!! üí™üëä

Sometimes we recognize members who are closely associated with someone who did a major Kick Up.  This past week, American tennis star, Taylor Fritz (ranked #14 in the world) won the men's professional grass court tennis tournament in Eastbourne, United Kingdom.  Eastbourne is a warm-up event for The Championships at Wimbledon.  My good mate, Wolfgang Oswald, is Taylor's personal physio!! CONGRATS TO YOU BOTH! üéâüëä

Good buddy, Cosi Belloso, is kicking it up this week by giving of her services in Guatemala for people with prostheses!! BRAVO, COSI!! üôåüôå

James St. Cyr and his wife, Sarah Jean,  KICKED IT UP this week!  Welcome, Miss Molly James!! ü•≥ü•≥

How about Nate Turner.  He PR'd in his 10K race by SIX minutes!! üëä

Excited for Susie Singer Parnell!! She just said "YES!" to her man, Stephen!! She's getting married!! üéâüéâ

Also saying "YES!" was Heather Gaydos!! She and her man, AJ, got engaged!!!! CONGRATS!!! üéâüéâ

Nothing like returning home from a trip to Barcelona and receiving a welcome home gift that recognizes you for your clinical excellence in recognition of outstanding patient care, communication, documentation, and making it all look easy!  CONGRATS on your award, Gustavo Arana!! BRAVO!! üéâüôåüëä

I am sure there are many many wins out there!! GREAT JOB, EVERYONE!!!

It's a holiday weekend.  MAKE IT FANTAWESOME!! 

Note: Photo is of Kalyca Jin Zarich, admin assistant for UNCAGED.  Today is her one year UNCAGED anniversary!!! ü•≥üéâ

post_text: California PTs‚Ä¶do we need any personal training certifications to be able to do personal training/performance/wellness coaching? I read our practice act and it sounds like it‚Äôs within our scope of practice ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

comments.text: Hi Luke, I am a PT and also a registered yoga instructor. I practice in MD but went to school in Cali so I‚Äôm somewhat familiar with the practice act there. I would say this is mostly a liability issue. We can never truly take our ‚ÄúPT hat‚Äù off even when training folks/ teaching group exercise. However, it does help to have a separate cert to help distinguish those services from your other PT work. So I‚Äôd suggest getting a NASM CPT or CSCS depending on your population. I‚Äôm currently studying for CSCS for this exact reasoning for when my yoga clients want to do more performance training with me.
I'm a CA PT. It definitely is within our scope of practice, but I also maintain my CSCS, just to cover all bases and help distinguish sports performance training from physical therapy services.

post_text:
Hello everyone! I am a Physical Therapist in Florida right now and recently applied and got my LLC to start my own business, but we are moving for an unknown amount of time to Washington D.C. As of right now, I am not planning to get my physical therapy license there but would like to see people under the umbrella of wellness still. I have my STOTT Pilates certification and am a certified life coach. I did have my NASM Personal Training certificate a long time ago but let it lapse when I became a PT. How can I do this, legally? Is there anything extra I need to do or be cautious of? How do I or can I market myself when people ask? If we do end up staying longer, I would probably get my license in Virginia and join the PT COMPACT but as of now, DC is not part of the compact so, I‚Äôm curious about how I could offer wellness services in DC, but PT in Virginia, Maryland, etc? 

This is confusing, but I‚Äôve let that get in my way too long! Thanks

comments.text: I've offered wellness for years. Above is correct. Also any forms before working w a client should clearly state this is not PT, it's wellness. There's not much else. Get an insurance plan or if you have just add wellness/training to it, it's cheap.

My thoughts. You can advertise your degree of a DPT (no one can take that away) but call your services all wellness services. You can not say PT though bc that is what denotes a license in our PT, DPT credential. When I tried to report someone in Michigan calling themselves an athletic trainer who wasn't an athletic trainer the board said they could only discipline a clinician who was licensed. So overall if your offering wellness and not PT and not billing for it I would assume you have alot less restrictions.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello everyone! I am a Physical Therapist in Florida right now and recently applied and got my LLC to start my own business, but we are moving for an unknown amount of time to Washington D.C. As of right now, I am not planning to get my physical therapy license there but would like to see people under the umbrella of wellness still. I have my STOTT Pilates certification and am a certified life coach. I did have my NASM Personal Training certificate a long time ago but let it lapse when I became a PT. How can I do this, legally? Is there anything extra I need to do or be cautious of? How do I or can I market myself when people ask? If we do end up staying longer, I would probably get my license in Virginia and join the PT COMPACT but as of now, DC is not part of the compact so, I‚Äôm curious about how I could offer wellness services in DC, but PT in Virginia, Maryland, etc? 

This is confusing, but I‚Äôve let that get in my way too long! Thanks

COMMENT 1: I've offered wellness for years. Above is correct. Also any forms before working w a client should clearly state this is not PT, it's wellness. There's not much else. Get an insurance plan or if you have just add wellness/training to it, it's cheap.

COMMENT 2: My thoughts. You can advertise your degree of a DPT (no one can take that away) but call your services all wellness services. You can not say PT though bc that is what denotes a license in our PT, DPT credential. When I tried to report someone in Michigan calling themselves an athletic trainer who wasn't an athletic trainer the board said they could only discipline a clinician who was licensed. So overall if your offering wellness and not PT and not billing for it I would assume you have alot less restrictions.

post_text:
The transition of going from an employee to solo business owner generally pales in comparison to the transition of going from solo to having employees. Being and becoming a better leader is essential to long term growth and sustainability in business. 

I'm hosting a 6 week leadership development intensive starting next Wednesday to help you grow and develop as a leader.  

Want to join? 

Comment LEAD and I'll reach out with more details.

comments.text: What day and time (EST) is this course?

Let‚Äôs go! I‚Äôve got something to say on this: if you are a solopreneur, you are the CEO. You must be able to lead yourself before you can grow enough to be able to lead others. Leading others (and also raising children which is also leading others) is the most challenging thing you will ever do. Grow yourself to be able to effectively lead others. Lots of people talk about having great teams where they can truly be the CEO and be able to see less patients‚Ä¶well, believe me, you better learn how to lead others‚Ä¶and it starts by learning how to lead yourself. 

I can‚Äôt think of anyone better to lead this program in Kevin DeGroot. Learn from him. He‚Äôs too humble to say it but he does a damn good job at leading his team at T-Zero. Being able to learn from him and how he is able to lead from a perspective of faith is invaluable, and possibly one of the most important things that people need to learn. We need more leaders, and leaders go first.
